151352530.review: Great Deckbuilder that instead of random cards you build a tetris style backpack. Very interesting choices to make compared to the normal games in this genre

151346886.review:
Turn-based roguelite with a focus on inventory management and "tetris-ing" all the things you want in your inventory, while jugging the fact that things buff/debuff different types of items next to them.

This game did one of the best early-access dev stories I've ever seen. Released a free trial on their website running unity in the browser, then released to steam when it was finished enough to warrant someone paying for it, then continued to update the game even after it was already a feature complete game. They added new characters, new game modes, and now a story mode. Amazing game with an amazing team behind it.

151333345.review: Novel rougelike that has pioneered its own subgenre, yet still gets everything right. The infinite combos and exploitable interactions from beta seem to have been balanced and ironed out, while the number of viable builds has skyrocketed. It used to be a game where I felt forced to save scum in order to get the build that I needed to succeed, but now I'm happy to notice I haven't reloaded a save a single time. I'm very happy with the current game state and I love the addition of the town.

It's not for me. I like the concept, but I have some major issues:
-The early runs are extremely short, so you don't really feel like you are getting a "build".
-The early runs are all the same place, with some slightly different rules but ultimately similar builds.
-The town building isn't really fun, and takes a good amount of time.

I'd prefer to just have longer runs with more chance to create a "build" rather than just grinding the same stuff over and over. Maybe it happens later in the game, but 5 hours in I'm already bored.

151211875.review:
A rogue-like dungeon adventuring game with turn-based combat. The main mechanic is essentially inventory tetris. No only do you have to select which items you want to take with you (and you can't take everything,) but the location and positioning of items in your inventory can massively change their combat effectiveness.

It was nice to see the addition of a "Story Mode" for the full release. The story is simplistic, but effective. Some of the challenges are more annoying than fun (especially the Mayor's.) 

You can ignore the story entirely and just do runs with a character. Each of the characters has their own set of unique mechanics so there are dozens, if not hundreds of possible builds. Even with the depth of builds available, the dungeon can get kind of repetitive after multiple runs.

151211139.review: The first 20 hours or so are absolutely excellent. When I wasn't playing this game, I was thinking about it. The gameplay itself is very fun, but what really makes it special is the inventory management. Trying to juggle dungeon survival with bringing items home to unlock new items was such a fun gameplay loop. Unfortunately, some of the later characters don't contribute to this at all. In the late game, I had nothing more to unlock or use my currency on. It seems like the developers tried to implement too many systems at once, resulting in many of these systems being abandoned in the late game.

151182057.review:
[h1]Backpack Hero.[/h1]

A game that even from the very start of its days on itch io, had me utterly addicted. [i]"They finally turned that flash game, Help The Hero, into something bigger!"[/i] was my initial thought. The simple premise but satisfying roguelike mix of organization and tactics to conquer challenges before you was more than enough to keep going, and [i]holy,[/i] did it keep going. Update after update. New enemies, events, characters, items! Changes to how mechanics work, characters that flip the base mechanics on their head but are equally as satisfying to figure out and play with. Until finally the full release was out. Eight days ago I was addicted all over again. Finding a myriad of new challenges and ways to play. The story mode's execution is done amazingly to help new players learn and experienced players try new things. Not to mention a city organizing mechanic, which just simply makes sense to put alongside the gameplay, like how it makes sense to put items that boost each other next together. Everything in its place and yet every run can change on a dime due to the sheer amount of items there are. The story itself is all up to you to discover. Items spawn that give more depth to the world you play in and makes you wonder what's still out there, whether it's in the game or not. I know that these developers will keep giving us fresh content, they've done nothing but improve and expand over and over again.

I completed the full list of achievements 8 days after release, becoming the [i]very first[/i] player to do so, and that I just about doubled my playtime in that period alone. There is easily 60+ hours of content in story mode and challenges and near infinite replay value. That amount is only going up from here, I have absolute faith in that. 

My only real wish for this game is for more Satchel costumes. He was already my favorite character and seeing him with more personality through story mode was awesome. 

Completing this was one of the best experiences I had while gaming, and it will be for you too.

151179528.review: Fun game with a unique concept and great music + tons of replayability

151176988.review:
Good game if you enjoy dungeon crawls or rogue likes; has a bit of a deckbuilding game feel but the deck is your Backpack that expands as you level up. Doesn't feel too addictive either, but that's subjective to each player.

Important features to note:
+Can be played one handed (mouse covers everything) However, I'd like to see a clickable button for rotating  items and accessing the context menu (currently limited to Right click).  Then it could be a one button game, which I think is important for accessibility users.  Regardless, It's nice to have a free hand to smoke/drink/pet a cat with.  However, the game also has controller options of course.

+It's not timed nor time intensive.  Actions are turn based, exploration waits on your commands. Can be walked away from and still be okay to play coming back. Runs are usually done within 30 minutes or less.

+Lots of build variety - There's multiple projectile styles, Melee variates with buffs and powers, Magic is odd with a networked system based on item conduits (mana is an expendable)

I WOULD like to see them add quick time events or puzzles to the dungeon (Indiana Jones style events would be fitting.)  Right now, the special events are mostly gambling and multiple choice options.  DLC could remedy that if the devs are feeling feisty. 

Either way, not a bad way to spend 10-15 bucks, they did a good job.  The music is a bit of an earbug tho; reminiscent of SNES melodies (the whole game is basically SNES style) which the loops get repetitive QUICKLY.  Would like to have more music tracks so i don't have to mute it.

151165690.review:
Backpack hero managed to be a masterpiece and a complete mess of a game at the same time, culminating in what is possibly my most frustrated experience in a long time.
Imagine you play a roguelite like Slay the Spire, Enter the Gungeon, Binding of Isaac or Risk of Rain. You start a run, you have fun, you unlock things along the way depending on your actions. It's great, it's a fun time. Now imagine, in-between every run, if you want to unlock anything or even see later levels of the game, you have to run across a huge open field, talk to 10 NPCs randomly scattered along the map (the game won't tell you which one you need or in what order), sit through endless repetitive dialogue that goes nowhere about how your dad thinks it's dangerous to go into the cave over and over and over again. Not only that, but it wants you to build endless buildings, sell loot you've found in the dungeon (the game doesn't tell you if you'll need them for anything or not), and it constantly want you to check in on every single NPC to even receive missions or get the pleasure of going to the next floor in future dungeon runs.
Even if you know what you're doing, it takes forever to get anything done in the main hub.
Every item you ever collect in the dungeon (a lot, this is an inventory manage game after all) is collected in your hub inventory. An NPC may be looking for one specific item, you might even have it, but good luck finding it
* The game does nothing to tell you what is important in the NPC town, so you have to spam every dialogue and every option select for every character just to make sure you don't miss anything.
And to top it all off, the game is insultingly easy. If you have ever played a deckbuilder (roguelite or not) or any form of strategy game, it will be almost impossible to lose as long as you read the effects of what you are using. Heck, even when I completely failed to do that and I accidentally burned my only arrow during my an archer-only "challenge", where every other game would kill you for failing to have any synergy or ways to deal consistent damage, I was able to win because an enemy dropped a rose earlier, letting enemies take very small amounts of damage every time I blocked. I was able to win, including beating a boss, dealing 1 damage at the time. Absolutely ridiculous. After 5+ hours of gameplay, every run feels like this. It is so easy it is almost insulting. There is never any risk, never any challenge, nothing that makes you reconsider your choices, and once you get a powerful weapon or two, never any need to think. Click the same inventory slots every turn, and win for free. Never the need to swap anything out of your inventory, which is a shame because it's one of the main mechanics.
All of this, and I still found myself wanting to play. There is a fantastic game deep down somewhere. Inventory management is fun, and having your inventory slots tied to abilities you can freely use is creative and fun. It is such a shame it is held back by you never needing to engage with its systems due to the absolute lack of difficulty, to the point where I have won games by not adding or removing anything from my inventory. Furthermore, when the game forces you to engage with its systems in the hub world, it strips the game of everything that made it fun, including making the graphics look like Backpack Hero from Wish. It is tedious, stays in the way of what could be a fantastic game, and despite hours of gameplay, you are still stuck with the same starter loadout you begun with. It's a shame.

151156101.review:
(I've nominated this game for the Sit Back and Relax Steam Award)
I've backed this game up in May 2022 when it launched on Kickstarter, and it's been a pleasure following the development of the game. For the few bucks, it offers an alright story mode, which is more of a way to ease you into the game, and the hundreds of different items there are in the game and gives you a bit of context and story bits about the different characters. I feel slightly invested as you do spend some time in the town and chat with folks, all giving you some piece of advice or silly quotes.
There's also a quick game mode for even more chaotic runs to do.
(Warning: Do not start Quick mode unless you want to get spoiled about story/cosmetics/character unlocks/item unlocks)

Very few games manage to make me bring along consumables and actually make me use them in tough spots (I'm one of those "but what if I need this potion later on?", thanks RE). The game has a lot of charm, the backpack system with limited space, quirky sorting depending what items you get (some items can be tilted different ways for different effects) and just overall the sheer amount of builds always gives you plenty of different things to try each run. Every character also comes with their own quirk and playstyle, so there's multiple ways to tackle a run.

Wanna be a chonky tank who defeats their opponents by shielding up to absurd numbers and win by damage reflecting? You can do that.
Wanna be a bard and flute yourself to victory? Also possible.
Or do you fancy being a mage cooking up the most evil active/passive abilities that render your enemies attacks useless in a span of a few turns? Check, can do.
There's plenty more, but I think to give someone an idea what you can do depending on the RNG, these examples should be fine.

Overall I can't think of many negative things to say about it other than distinguishing between rarity of items is sometimes a chore (you have to mouseover each item to reveal their info), which in the beginning you will do a lot.
I encountered minor visual bugs in story mode, which usually get fixed by reloading the save.
In dungeon runs sometimes the mouseover items in special events doesn't work. I assume it's because your backpack inventory in the background clips through the event window, so the game has a hard time to tell which item you wanna check.
But it's honestly just nitpicking, and bug fixes for the game come along pretty frequently.

Adéntrate en la mazmorra y recoge cosas. Equípate armas, escudos y puede que algún objeto maldito. 
Amplia la mochila. Haz tetris! Reorganiza y vuelve a reorganizar. 
Equípate más objetos y consumibles que guardarás para después. Por si acaso, claro... 
Vuelve a reorganizar.
Amplia la mochila de nuevo, para llenarla en el siguiente combate y vuelve a reorganizar.
Recoge ese objeto raro que cambia la build que llevas, pero que parece mejor, para volver a organizar el inventario y queriendo optimizar.

Pero no es necesario. El juego es sencillo, divertido y fácil de pillar. Tiene mecánicas curiosas y entretenidas. Si vas con calma es difícil perder. Si quieres dificultad tienes el modo hardcore y el infinito. O en el modo historia, tratar de quedarte objetos específicos junto a maximizar la recompensa mientras vas con una build cochambrosa que va tirando.

151097347.review:
I would love to give this game a thumbs up.  On the surface and at the start, it seems really fun.  Perhaps I'm missing something here, but:

The problem I ran into is the strategy element of figuring out builds kind of falls apart after a few runs.  It incentivizes you to try different builds by giving you a quest that requires you to play with certain items.  The main issue is that those different play styles are not actually viable.  So, take an archery build for example:  You use a bow and you get arrows.  Arrows do a set amount of damage based on the how many empty columns there are to the right.  Your bow will automatically fire arrows to the right of it, so you instantly get a damage nerf because you have to place the bow to the left, then the arrows to the right of that, then damage is based on how many empty columns there are to the right of that.  This also has the additional negative of making you choose between picking up items and leaving empty spaces so you do decent damage.  You would think that having items that give you dodge would be great, a few items that allow you dodge attacks so you can save space for your arrows and damage.  I found one item that give you dodge, it can be used one time per round and it gives you one.  You can hold 30 of these, but good luck finding more than a couple in a run.  You are force to choose items that give you block in this scenario.

I ran to a similar problem with a magic build.  For that you get items that increase your mana, and items that restore your mana.  So it starts you with a ring that uses 1 mana to add 4 block, an item that holds 2 mana, and a magic staff.  You would think that you are concerned only with mana in a build like this and it would replace energy.  It doesn't though.  You have to juggle energy and mana.  This wouldn't be so bad, but unlike energy, your mana doesn't refill every round, only every battle.  Your magic staff, on use, restores one mana to your "mana network" for the first attack of every round.  You pick up magic wands that use mana charges, like your ring that give you block.  You pick up more of these mana stones or shards as you play, so your mana pool gets larger.  That sounds good, right?  Sounds very interesting?  It would be if the wands, which are weapons that use mana, were worth anything.  You may get wands that do a little damage, or give you a little regen, stuff like that, but it never really popped off.  At no point are you doing anything but hitting enemies with your magic staff and sometimes using a wand sometimes.  Once again... you are forced to use items that give you block and filling your inventory with them so you can survive through your mission.

Most builds start you with some very basic items.  For example, the magic build above starts off with just those things.  A basic fighter will be a shield, a wood sword, and some food.  And the idea is that you build based on things you come across as you play.  But here is another misstep for the game.  Early on, you rarely see any items that is not just a basic item.  Lots of times you have to be deeper into the dungeon in order to find better items, which would be fine except that you basically start with the exact same build every single time to get to later floors.  So, you stock up on things like a good melee weapon, a decent shield, perhaps a bunch of armor to give you block, then  you can't really switch based on a piecemeal items you find after battles or in chests since enemy groups have more enemies in them that do different things AND do more damage. 

My biggest issue with the builds is that taking a basic melee weapon and loading up on armor gives you a 100% success rate on any run.  They try to steer you different ways, but the only time I have failed a run is with any build other than the basic melee build.  And that is mostly because there are a ton of armor pieces that give you block, but only 1 that gives you dodge.  So why use that one at all, when you can wear 7 other helmets, 3 sets of shoes, two types of chest armor, and a few kinds of gloves that all give you block.  And that will take up my inventory by a lot, but it will make that run successful every single time.  

The town building is not fun either.  I thought it would be awesome, but you just kind place stuff where ever you want and it doesn't matter all the much.  You get research or selling bonuses for having certain decorations around it, lots of times you have to do later quests to unlock any of those decorative items.  Like, you have about 6 different types of things that take research before you get a town hall which you connect to via walkways so you can do all your research from the town hub rather than walking to each building.  The interface here is not very good either.  When you are in a certain menu, you may be inclined to hit escape to back out of it.  Nope, brings up the game menu.  You have to click on a back arrow that is on the interface to back out of menu.  Sometimes that takes you completely out of it and sometimes it takes you back one layer, so it's incredibly inconsistent.  NPC are also running all over the place, so if you are looking for a certain NPC, they are hard to find.

There are NPCs in the dungeon you can run into as well.  But they are very underwhelming.  You run into one, and for a few gold it will give you a random weapon, shield, or food items.  But I have never been happy with anything I have got, nothing that you could consider a game changer at all in terms of how you are playing.  Another one will let you roll dice to get an item, but once again, nothing that will change how you play.  There are shops, which have random things in them, which is where you are most likely going to find anything that may have you try something different.  There is an NPC that forges items in the dungeon, but it will give you 4 random choices, and those choices may not have anything to do with how you want to play.  One time it will offer more block on armor, more block on shields, more damage on a weapon, or to make something "Conductice", which adds energy to the mana pool.  Another time it may offer to add poison to a weapon, or add weakness, or add spikes to a shield, but not every item can be upgraded, and most items can only be upgraded once so it's not like you can turn a melee build into a magic build by adding conductivity to your all your armor and buying a wand.  It just doesn't work.

So, the game feels chaotic and unfocused.  And in being that way, makes it so only a single build type is viable.  You are never given a way to start your run, so you basically get funneled the same each run because you are doing a quest of your choice before you start out, and it feels like a waste to not accomplish that quest.  There are a ton of quests that unlock more things, but you are never really driven to complete any given thing because it feels like more of the same. 
 Even if you unlock the Fletcher building to upgrade bows, playing with an archery build just makes it so easy for you to die that it feels like a waste of your time.

I don't think I have given up on this game yet, but I don't know how much more of the "same" thing I have in me.  I just can't suggest it.  Great concept, delivery is very poor.  And by god, find some music you want in the background because the same 2 chip tunes playing constantly will make you have the music in this game.  The music is just incredibly boring.

151014627.review:
Excellent, innovative gameplay that spawned an entire genre of copycats (I'm looking at you, backpack Battlers). 

The meta-progression / story mode is currently a bit scuffed and certainly needs work on, but gives players a host of different challenges as you upgrade your arsenal of weapons or take on specific 'quests' which are effectively challenge modes.

With the exception of Tote, all the characters have fun and interesting variations on the inventory management gameplay, with their unique items to match their gameplay. It's fun to build borderline broken builds and dominate your opposition with clever use of what you've found.

Tote, unfortunately, has glaring issues that make her miserable to play. The backpack mechanic, coupled with Tote being forced to rely on Slay-The-Spire deck-building, oppose each other rather than synergize and make even easy mode difficult to complete without careful planning. She NEEDS a rework.

150993847.review:
I adore the complexity of the gameplay, while keeping actions simplistic.
It is easy to understand, and all tooltips are very handy and direct in explaining interactions and effects.

(Played more than just 2 hours as of writing)
Most games are learned rather quickly, then completed over time. Backpack hero has so many possible builds, interactions and synergies that you can keep exploring and trying out interesting mechanics. I recently unlocked another character (Tote), which to my surprise completely overhauled the gameplay mechanics, almost doubling gameplay mechanics.

It's refreshing having a simplistically styled game not shy away from depth.

Though, I agree that the rest of the game is a bit 'unpolished'. Akward city-building and town's people interaction. Large textboxes. Too much text with little content. No easy separation between 'info' and 'story' text. But these are all secondary to the core of the game, and can be worked on if important enough.

For difficulty, the game is still easy given enough time to min-max my build (and a bit of luck), but I see a lot of potential for difficulty through restrictions and challenges. (Need to play more to find out)

[u][b][h1]Good:[/h1][/b][/u]
[list]
[*] Fun rogue-lite with a good mix of interesting mechanics and various character types.
[*] Chill and cute aesthetic and character design.
[*] Satisfying and sometimes ridiculously overpowered build potentials.
[*] Active and thoughtful dev team who communicates regularly and openly with their community.
[/list]

[u][b][h1]Meh:[/h1][/b][/u]
[list]
[*] Like many rogue-likes, repetition and poor RNG can feel bad when luck isn't on your side.
[*] Music score is cute and nostalgic, but not for everyone.
[*] Clarity on certain mechanics could be better.
[/list]

[u][b][h1]Bad:[/h1][/b][/u]
[list]
[*] Certain character mechanics don't stand out as much as I would like.
[*] Bosses don't often feel very distinct.
[/list]

I backed on kickstarter and have absolutely loved this game and the amount it's grown since I first started playing. The dev team have done an incredible job keeping the community in the loop with updates and taking community feedback in stride. The satisfaction of playing this game comes in the relative quirky simplicity of the gameplay loop mixed with the general concept. It feels to me like a perfect chill low effort gameplay on those days where I don't need all the action but want the challenge and joy of figuring out how to be completely overpowered when a build comes together. Figuring out some of the characters can be a bit of a pain, but they are really enjoyable once you get the hang of some of them. The different game modes that have been added leading up to and with the 1.0 release land this game in a wholehearted recommend for anybody who loves card battler/rogue-lites, and for all who have ever felt like their inventory management skills in other RPGs should've been rewarded.

[b] Before anything, Pochette may be stinky, but she is still best girl. [/b]

I'll be very honest in this review, I played this game so much in the early access in a really short period of time that I got kinda bored of it and I couldn't stand it for months, so I had a positive first impression and I didn't enjoy the game for some time, but now... I think this game is amazing. Version 1.0 is all this game needed.
This game has really cool pixel art and soundtrack and an innovative gameplay, space management and turn RPG go really well with each other. My main problem with the game in early access was that it caused a really good impression, but once I got experienced, I found myself repeating the same builds again and again just for the sake of winning, because the game is very punishing in certain bosses if you don't use the right weapons and I found no purpose on completing the game again and again because it was the same ending all over again. 
Now though, I think it's perfect with the story mode! The game gave you a purpose to go down the dungeon, because you get new information, lore about the world and different dialogues each time you go back to the village, I'm really enjoying the journey to find Purse's mom. It's not repetitive anymore either, because the game forces you to do different builds each time you descend into the dungeon in order to get the items to progress the story, so both things complement each other.
In my opinion it's finally an amazing game now, probably the best indie from 2023, so mainly if you like strategy games and pixel art, go for it.

150773108.review:
I love this game

So, I started playing this in the beta stages and was happy with it then, yes it was repetitive but it has the replay value with it being a rouge-like game. 
Now that it is fully released I love it even more, I enjoy the characters in the town and building it back, dungeon crawling, painstakingly getting rid of items to create space in my backpack for better ones. 

You can make mistakes by not reading items properly, you can upgrade to unlock new potential items in one of your dungeon crawls. 
It does start off easy, but believe me... It can get hard, you will die, especially if you don't pay attention to what items do in the backpack! 

I love love LOVE the main screen music, it's so catchy and I could listen to it for ages. It just gives a very upbeat feeling before you know you are going to die and re-do the dungeon again. 

I'm still early days into the full release, so maybe I'll find an issue but, so far so good. 
I would say the only thing I would like them to potentially update, is the villager tab - This lets you click on the villager icon and will walk you over there.

HOWEVER - 
It would be better for it to say who they are and what they do. 
As it does this if you are near them and hover your mouse of them, but not in the little side menu...Which would save me time trying to find the girl that looks at certain items. 

But I would recommend to anyone that likes a deck-builder, dungeon crawler, rouge-like game. 
It is great to sink hours into or a game that you just want to play for 30 mins to kill some time.

Backpack Hero is a combination of several different things:
A dungeon crawler with always random map layouts
A rougelite
A Town builder
A turn based RPG
All with a Resident Evil 4 inventory system and a random loot system. Backpack Hero released it's 1.0 version not too long ago and while further polishing of the game is needed(A better way to find specific NPC's in town to talk to them would be nice.) It is a solid dungeon crawling game that never plays the same way twice and with 5 playable characters, around 200 enemies to fight and numerous unlockables, this game does it's best to make sure you won't get bored with it anytime soon!

150525079.review:
The game is great. I just wish to critique one thing.

Backpack Hero is a game that has amazing gameplay but honest to god far too much writing for what it is supposed to be. Im not saying it cant have a story. Im not even saying it shouldnt explain its story. But it comes to a point where a fairly simple story you want to enjoy inbetween runs turns into almost a visual novel type of reading scenario.

This btw is about the main campaign, not the general gameplay you can enjoy just as much. But if you play the campaign and wish to unlock everything, its practically gated behind needing to talk to people constantly. And some of these are hidden behind message after message after message.

The town needs a mayor. Alright. There is a guy who asks you to make a townhall so the town can be run again. Fair and simple. Then why does this need to be dragged on into a full back and forth of the main character and this character? Yea I get it, we aint playing ourselves. We playing the main character. There is a story to be played no matter what. But if I were to compare this to a game like "Plague Tale" in which we too play a character, the dialogue never felt like it slowed down the game.

If you are really into the story then sure, this has it in spades. Lots of details, lots of characters, lots of worldbuilding. Its great. But if you wanna play what is a roguelike deckbuilder, you are not here to read a visual novel worthy story. Dark Souls, which has a ton of story, backstory and lore to boot makes it so players can choose to read up on it. And I feel this is much to its advantage. Cause if you had to read up on the lore of every armorset, weapon, spell or Bosssoul each time you find it, it would slow down the gameplay to a crawl and would lead to refunds more often than not.

--

Again. There is nothing wrong with the game having a story. But if I have to click though dialogue up to 10-15 times just to get to simple research or other new mechanics, thats a bit excessive.

The addition of a campaign really elevated this game from great to amazing. The meta-progression brings an interesting risk-reward to the game, where you're incentivized to take items which may not be the best for your current build, or which you may not be used to, in order to unlock things back in the hub. It forces you to experiment and interact with the game's systems, which is great! The combination of inventory and resource management leads to interesting decision-making in the dungeon, and it feels satisfying when you make a build that clicks!

Personally, I wish the game was a bit more difficult, but it's still challenging enough to be satisfying!

150504741.review:
One of the best games I've played in a really long time, deserving of being in the GOAT discussion with the likes of Enter the Gungeon.

The core loop works incredibly well, there is a lot of diversity, the meta progression is extensive, and there are very few instances where you end up in a set it and forget it build. 

The ramp in difficulty and the variety of enemies is at a really good point where if something you have works, you feel pretty great about it, but you do need to stay mindful about branching your build out for when you get hit with a new enemy type or the difficulty ramps. 

 I think that there's some tertiary systems that aren't polished, but I view those as welcome and surprising additions. The base building aspect for example. Didn't know that I wanted it, but glad it's there.

You've got a decent story, new town building/managing (yay more management) elements, progression, a lot of different quests etc.

The sessions in between runs is atrocious. Having to turn an item into one of these at the town can easily turn into 5 minutes of running in circles clicking on every single npc until you accidentally stumble on the right one who will take your item. I write this review after wasting 10 full minutes running around town clicking every single npc in the entire game only to find that not a single one of them will take this "mysterious letter" and it cant be used as a recipe to learn a new asset so... What the ****? I feel like the gameplay is great until you get punched in the dick with this little town-builder minigame that is a cool idea but is SO frustrating to actually use. I rec the game right now because of the fact that the actual gameplay is great and because I believe that the awful little in-between-runs portion is easily fixable. If the player has an item they need to turn in then for the love of god put a fucking indicator on the npc. guessing which one you need to turn it into isnt gameplay its annoying and tedious and leaves a bad taste in the players mouth. You already have that system in place there is red exclamation marks used to show a quest giver, so WHY does it not work with items? why is THAT a guessing game made only to completely waste your time? 150480141.review:
The core game play is a lot of fun. Lots of different mechanics to create interesting and varied builds, and quests that prompt trying different build types, which gives it a lot of replay value. 

The one downer is the weirdly sloppy home base you return to between runs. The graphics in the main portion of the game are lovely refined pixel art with a lot of charm. The town looks like it was thrown together last minute, with none of the same visual appeal. The town building mechanics feel equally thrown together, and it just isn't fun to have to do. Trying to put down buildings is a chore, and it often feels arbitrary which placements of buildings are legal. For example, you can't place paths/structures behind a building with no obstructions, while some buildings can be placed adjacent with each other and others can't, which makes making an appealing layout impossible. The pathways you can put down don't even align with the entryway of the buildings. 

The town building is a very small part of the game, and doesn't detract too much from an otherwise very polished product. You aren't forced to engage with it too much, since doing enough runs will get you most of the materials you need without needing to optimize the home base. 

Overall a great game, sitting in a nice medium complexity for a rogue-like, where it's not boringly easy or overly in need of min-maxing to create interesting combos to succeed.

150439815.review:
I have to say. This is one of the most novel games I've played in a while. 

When I first played it a while ago, I expected it to be a gimmick I'd get tired of inside of a couple hours, but it's proven to be more or less endlessly replayable(even before story mode was added) due to the number of builds and kludged together runs you'll manage to play.

The new story mode update is fantastic, and all of the little item-specific micro runs it has you do while making your way through it is very nice. The quickplay gametypes are rad, but they're mostly difficult tweaks,. The story mode quest runs are cool with giving you specific items to make entire builds around. Very satisfying and introduces build concepts very naturally.

Big fan of this game across the board, I really can't recommend it enough.
Fun art, charming characters, engaging and thought provoking gameplay. Solid winner across the board.

150435591.review:
I loved the demo when it was out for play on your browser. Somehow, it feels like the full release is worse than that demo. You're only allowed to do act 1 for the first 8 runs or so, and then you're allowed to do act 1 and 2... in the demo you could do everything if you had a strong run, there weren't artificial barriers that prevented progress. 

Which is a huge issue in this game. 90% of the items are locked and must be unlocked one or two at a time. Each time I finish a run I get to choose and unlock like one or two items. Even in the unfinished demo, the item pool was like 3x larger than what you start with in the full release... it feels wild to say that. 

This whole unlock mechanic severely kills the enjoyment that I had for the demo version. I loved finding items that synergize and create combos that flip my whole strategy for each fight. In this full version, those items are locked and you have to fulfil difficult requirements to unlock...

Why am I forced to do 100 "basic" runs  before I'm allowed to start playing the version of the game I already know that I'd enjoy more than this?

As far as things I dislike go, you can unlock bags to put inside your bags, but it gets a bit janky, especially with the guy who can send items from the dungeon to the town with. That guys bag closes any time you open one of yours, which means everything you want to send back has to be in your main bag, which is tedious.

Great, cozy dungeon crawler in a rough shape.

Ultimately, the gameplay deserves an upvote, but I would recommend waiting until things are more polished. The game is lagging quite a bit in your town, certain interactions softlock your UI, quest text not loading, gameplay balance, etc. 
As others commented already, the town building mechanic falls flat - it would be much better if it were slimmed down or reworked completely (Get rid of efficiency, houses, and at best all gathering buildes as well)

On a more positive note, I enjoyed the story mode quite a bit, It's a great tutorial to explore the game mechanics, even though the story itself is quite terrible. Different quests provide incentives to play various builds, highlighting what each item is capable off

Unfortunately, I cannot recommend the game due to the state it's in right now. There are simply too many bugs, balance issues and oversights in general to recommend it over other indie games. It's not early access anymore and it's still a long way from being finished.

150275645.review:
The 1.0 release is live - a few (6) months late but still welcome. The game retains all of its charm and novelty. The town building is fun and the progression does not feel forced. There aren't too many bugs that I've run into playing ~15 hours of the new version and none that are major.

HOWEVER. The reason I do not recommend is because they still haven't changed the most glaringly obvious broken issue on the summoner class - being able to recall pets more than 1 time a turn. All you need to do is choose one of the 0 summon cost pets (which if memory serves you always have the option to get) and get the Pet Bed item which sleeps (miss a turn) an enemy on summon. With the ~3 starting energy the class has you can recall+summon time-lock every single fight in the entire game. The run is over you cannot physically lose. The bosses can't summon men because they are time locked. There is maybe 1 or 2 minion fights  (that you might not even encounter) late game with more mobs than the free summon + energy-costing resummons you have by default cannot perma-lock and by that point you will have other items that would coast you over (or maybe you have some energy items so you can time lock all 5 by then).

The only piece of the "combo" you need to assemble is the 1 item. As soon as you do, you "win" that run, no gameplay needed anymore. Given that this interaction remains exactly the same as the beta tells me worrying things about how little balance was considered for this release. As in not at all - which is worrying for a game that advertises that proper management of the backpack is rewarding. All they had to do was limit recalls to 1 time per turn or maybe with a +1 cost each time (and the combination would still have you breeze through most fights), and they had at least 6 months to implement this change.

I will edit this review as it becomes pertinent.

150263421.review:
This game is offline-acheivement compatible, built on itself, and is rather quite nice at 1.0 inasmuch as it was great years back, AND being the OG backpack novel paradigm, it's got a lot going for it there on (within a turn-based energy system).

Though, given the 1.0 release, there should be some edits or at least MORE PREFACING to the town--inasmuch as 'new runs' don't seem like carrying old equipment but every post-run equipment seems...saved, it was somewhat confusing there to see.

Still, always will have a lovely place in my heart--also because of the diversity of characters, especially when at a time it was released, there was like, not that much focus on not-male-human characters in many places and themes (or if there was a need for such, it'd be put down under some dissonance by even devs than merely players). Love to see this going forward as, way back before 1.0, me and all those close to me had the idea of "wow this has so much going for it; backpack hero is 1000% more amazing than it has any right to be".

Any issues right now seem to be more of tiny mechanical stuff than anything inherently gamebreaking given knowing the language of this game (or moreso, its design relationship). It still screams "we have to pick which fits best" and I'm sorely glad it isn't just "SHOVE ALL THE WEAPONS IN THERE" because the world isn't just 'poke enemy dead'.

P.S. Went online to get enough minutes to review/recommend :P But this has been with me for years and I can recall everything from the different end-runs to divergent plot points.

150257185.review: Got this game on the kickstart, best decision ever!

150257092.review:
EDIT: After doubling my playtime, I decided to change this negative review to a positive review. I was impressed with the amount of items and playstyles available, always keeping runs fresh. And to top it off, unlockable characters that each have their own unique backpack mechanics and add a twist to it. My original criticism with the town still stands, and I really wish the UI there wasn't as clunky, but I am starting to get used to it now.

=======================
ORIGINAL REVIEW BELOW


I'll start off by saying, this game is fun and I want to play it more. It is definitely not a bad game.

The combat is very fun, the art style in the dungeon is great and gameplay feels reminiscent of Slay the Spire where mechanics are simple enough by themselves, but they combine in many fun ways and can lead to some very interesting interactions. The inventory management aspect could be better (the game Backpack Battles shows more promise there) but is still fun to interact with.

My main issue with the game and reason for the thumbs down is the hub and metaprogression. The beautiful pixel art from the dungeon gets scaled down here and as a result it looks a lot less charming to me, The overall gameplay here is pretty standard: spend currency you acquire during runs to unlock buildings who in turn can unlock items from their respective branch (weapons, magic, archery, etc.). You get some dialogue and story and are given quests to do in the dungeon and unlock more features.

The metaprogression sounds decent on paper, but the way it is executed is so incredibly tedious that it takes away any curiosity I had and even hindered my progress on some occasions. 
- NPCs are scattered around the place, there is a list available but it doesn't say what they do or even their name, it's just a portrait.
- one npc could unlock the next area for me but required a specific item. Once I got that item I spent a while talking to each NPC trying to remember which one wanted it. This happened with other NPCs too. Their portraits weren't even lighted up to indicate they had a pending task.
- the inventory is incredibly cluttered and not easy to navigate or even sort. When submitting items to an NPC that only accepts specific items like the Librarian, you still need to sift through your entire inventory looking for the scroll when all the other items there are invalid anyway.
- it's not always clear what you need to unlock certain things (e.g. an unlock required two shivs, I submitted one shiv and the two shiv icons were marked as completed)
- you get dozens of quests and it's not always easy figuring out which ones are important for progression and which ones are just unlocking a specific set of items or not that interesting
- items that boost efficiency can just be moved around as you need for a specific building, which is incredibly annoying to do but can help you save resource (I optimized the fun out of that mechanic, didn't I)
- Building menu mixes production buildings (repeatable) and one-time, REALLY important buildings you should definitely prioritize. Also it removes their icons once built so if you place a building in a corner you could just forget about it altogether.

I could list more but with so many rogue-like games out there, I was expecting a much better UI and systems there. I could easily do away with having a character to walk around in the hub. Just make it a smaller map where I can directly click each building without panning around, see what I have not built yet greyed out. Instead of having tons of individual unlocks where you read every single item and figure out what you should spend your currency on, make it gradually unlock (not add 12 items at once), or even unlock items automatically as you stock up that specific building with items and currency (i.e. upgrade buildings). That way you don't need to agonize over so many choices and just invest in the playstyle that you want to pursue.

I think the concept of the game is great, the combat is very well designed but a lot of stuff falls through in other areas and it creates this weird feeling of wanting to play more, but dreading having to handle the town part and being unsure about how to make runs as meaningful as possible (so many quests).

I am giving it a thumbs down for now for all the issues mentioned, if the UI for the metaprogression side was improved and some of the biggest pain points addressed, it would have a lot more potential and I would love to see that.

150169114.review:
A fantastic inventory management rogue lite.

You start with a couple of basic items and have to make you way to the bottom of the dungeon. Along the way you beat up monsters, gain xp (which increases your bag space), and find random weapons, armor and items. The aim is pretty much making the most of the random loot by trying to synergize items and to come up with a good strategy to build towards.

Every run is different from the huge pool of random items you'll collect and it makes for a hugely replayable game.

150158639.review:
As someone who adores dungeon crawlers, has a deep fondness for inventory management, and enjoys roguelikes, Backpack Hero is a game that was all but custom-made for me. I backed it on kickstarter, I put 40 hours into it during early access, and I waited patiently for full release to avoid burning out on the game. That makes it all the more bittersweet that the 1.0 release seems to be an endless stream of one step forwards and two steps back. For every quality of life improvement and interesting change to core mechanics, there has been an absolute glut of bloated and tacked-on metaprogression that serves mostly to be padding in the way of the core gameplay rather than an accompaniment. 

Building the city is finicky and slow, with a UI that's clumsy and a scale that makes it unclear why certain mechanics are there at all. Debris litters the town but you'll be able to clear almost all of it before you're even done with the tutorial challenges. There's so many poorly-differentiated NPCs who meander around that the devs put in the ability to home in on them through a menu, but not any explanation in that menu who they are or what they do. The core puzzle of moving items in your inventory and sequencing your turns is still wonderful if lacking in encounter variety, but it feels like the devs spent the past year wrapping that core in styrofoam rather than truly refining it. 

I still love this game, and am excited to spend more time delving into it and exploring what it has to offer, but that love is tempered by the knowledge that quite a bit of time and effort went into systems that didn't land.

150129999.review:
Backpack hero is an exercise in making the most out of some resources that are limited (energy, space), and others which are plentiful (consumables, money, items). It is part optimization, part risk assessment, and part engine building (like a deck builder, not like a car).

There is tons of variety in the ways you can play, both in what items you pick up to determine your "build", and in the different characters in the game that play very differently from each other.

The only real downside I might give it would be that the way things combine can get really out of hand, meaning if you make the right choices and get a bit lucky, the game becomes trivial and nothing can really challenge you. With that said, it can be really fun to see your build go off like that so it can be a plus too, but it also means you kind of just click through the game without meaningful choices after, so it can get a bit repetitive in some runs in that way.
There are a bunch of different run modifiers though that add challenges or just make the game harder, as well as challenging yourself for more difficult builds or characters you aren't as good with, so even though sometimes you might be phoning it in for a couple of floors at the end of a powerful run, you might find a proper challenge on the next one. If the Devs read this, really the one thing I would hope to see might be to change how the challenges work to more like toggles, so you can mix and match them, or at the least up/down the difficulty in a generic way on any run: If you feel that you need hard mode 3 to be challenging, not being able to have that difficulty when trying something like glass cannon might make it less interesting

Honestly I would recommend at least trying this game to everyone, there are ways to play that will fit so many different styles and skill levels.

The game has evolved a lot since the Itch.io version. Lot of new items, enemies, events, a whole town mode... All of these weren't exactly necessary as the game was fine and probably still would have sold, but all these things come together to make sure that it's worth your time. The bugs are few and far between and usually hammered out with each new patch, and the devs try their hardest to make the characters each unique and fun to play.

The ONLY gripes I have with the game are:
1: Tote is un-fun to play as, but thankfully you only need to play as her once to beat the story mode.
2: Forge events are how a lot of builds pop off, but you can get screwed with options sometimes.
3: Relic balance is a bit iffy.
4: There is currently no way to murder "mayor" Quillswish (yet).

Overall I rate the game a solid 8/10. A good game that you can relax to while still using your brain to an extent.

149843932.review:
I've been playing Backpack Hero since it was an online web-only game, and have loved it ever since. The unlimited ways in which you can develop your arsenal and defenses through careful planning and organization of your inventory is a fun and unique twist on character and game progression. Items have single, stand alone uses almost all of the time, however, it is the synergies that they possess and pass on to other items in your inventory that truly bring out their full power and potential. Sometimes they impact an adjacent item, sometimes it is an item nearby, and other times the impact can be on an item or multiple items in an entirely different part of your inventory!

Each of the current 5 heroes is unique in their own ways, with alternate ways of setting up their inventories and synergizing with items within. I personally love satchel, with is ability to charm your opponents with musical instruments and percussion. As your hero advances and defeats opponents, they are awarded experience. This experience is solely used at specific thresholds to allow you to increase not only your inventory size, but how it is shaped and laid out. You will find free chests and other rewards as you advance, and will accumulate gold over time from defeating opponents, finding it in the dungeon, and selling valuable, but unneeded items you find in your travels to one of the many vendors you encounter along the way. Gold can be used in the obvious way, to buy new items from those vendors, but can also be used in other ways to improve both your hero, and your items.

The addition of the story mode and ability to build your own version of the hero's town, called Haversack Hill, has really elevated the game to a whole new level. With fun, unique, and interesting challenges for all 5 of the game's unique heroes, you advance through dozens of different scenarios to meet and unlock each hero, and collect resources along the way to begin building your town from a field of ruined buildings and piles of debris into a thriving little community. As the town grows and more townsfolk are added through the construction of a variety of unique specialty buildings, you begin to unlock more and more items which can be found in future adventures into the dungeon.

The development team are a fun and friendly group who are always in touch with the community to hear ideas and get feedback on game mechanics and balancing issues. At the same time, they are also always working on new items and new heroes to add to the game. They are always within earshot on their friendly and helpful Discord as well as through the community page here on Steam. The gaming community is also fun to talk to and interact with. They're always full of fun and unique new strategies, and are willing to help newer folks understand how things work.

It is such a unique game that it is hard to describe to anyone who has not played it, as there really isn't any similar games that I'm aware of. The juggling many hundreds of available items obtained randomly through each adventure in an inventory of finite space is a fun and challenging puzzle each play through. With many more hours played than I care to admit, I have to say that this is one fun little game!

148669267.review:
Look, it's a pretty good game.

If you enjoy roguelikes deeply like me, then you'll love this game because it's gimmick is interesting.

If you're not a degenerate like me who has put 4 digit hours into Isaac, bought Cult of the Lamb day 1, figured out how to actually play Gungeon or even enjoys Nuclear Throne... then I'm sorry, this is a fun game, but it's not going to be worth $20 to you when Cult of the Lamb is $25, Isaac is... currently like $50 for the complete package but the base game is only like $5... hell, even Death Road to Canada is only like $15.

I'm not not recommending this game because it's not good, I'm not recommending it because despite the love and effort that has gone into this game, I don't think it deserves a $20 price tag when compared to the rest of the genre.

The beta branch is promising... but at the end of the day it is basically just adding in what Cult of the Lamb has already done better, and it's currently a buggy mess (it's not been pushed to the live branch yet, so that's understandable, but at this point the game without the new town-builder research progression system feels pretty shallow in comparison... plus if they weren't doing what they're doing in the beta branch, I'd just say outright there was no chance in hell the game would be worth a $20 price tag)

Now, for some positives:

You've got a Tetris/Tarkov/Neo Scavenger/whatever-the-hell-you-associate-it-with style inventory system at the core of a pseudo-deck-builder roguelike in which you are often confronted with choices to make about what is more deserving of bag space... or even if it's more worthwhile to leave space open for some items that utilize negative space.

You've got years worth of work that's gone into creating a ton of build possibilities and options so that you're not really going to have the same exact endgame in a run every time... unless you are going for a specific run type, but even then with the new beta branch stuff you can force an archetype for a run if you want to. At the end of the day though, you can just play a rat who pours beers from a keg, chugs about 5 pints, then shoves bombs in each mug and chucks them at enemies if you want to. Want to play an absolute tank that is so spike-ridden that enemies kill themselves on your body with their feeble attempts to harm you? Completely viable.

Aaaaaaaaand... that's kinda it for positives. I'm not going to give it credit for seeing Cult of the Lamb and following the trend, whether I enjoy that direction or not. I'm not going to give it credit for being a roguelike or having a furry-bait artstyle or taking years to add any sort of story to the game to explain what was going on... just to rewrite Made in Abyss for every other story beat.

So, you want some serious negatives?

Furry bait. Call it artistic choice, you know full well they aren't trying to harken back to old cartoons.

For as much archetype variety you can pick from while making a build mid-run, within those archetypes there's not that much variance. A lot of items exist just to be better/worse versions of other items.

Item bloat. While again, you can somewhat force archetypes with the beta system's themed runs, you'll find time and time again that you get a couple items for a build, decide to try and go with it, then never find anything else you're looking for. I'm not saying it's a horrible thing, but the heavily rng-dependence of this game's loot system will have a lot of people turning away.

It's surprisingly short. Again, if you aren't playing on the beta (which is buggy and still has some interesting balance changes in it) then a run consists of 9 floors, 3 bosses. After that you go into endless mode which is just going back to the top and going through 9 floors and 3 bosses except it has an insane power spike and 99% of builds that beat the 3rd boss won't get past the 4th. It's got replayability, but you're gonna have to still deal with the same issue FTL has in that you don't get a lot of time to really develop your build in a run (which, longer runs would help significantly with smoothing out all the rng-dependence)

If you want to play the beta, you have to deal with a fairly lackluster story, discount animal crossing voices, awkward ux and more awkward building mechanics... and worst of all... god damned Bee-Ear-Rape-Noises.wav

- all in all, it's a fun game, but if you're like a lot of us and you've got a monthly budget for spending on games, get this on sale. I know developers gotta eat too, but at the end of the day they're selling a product, you're buying a product, and right now their product is priced at about twice what it's really worth at the moment.

148480315.review:
I've spent around [i]5 hours[/i] on "Backpack Hero", completed [i]2 runs[/i] and here are my thoughts:

[b]What I Liked:[/b]
- Mixing inventory management with action is a unique and fun idea.
- Deciding what to carry and where to place them in your inventory is a fun challenge. You need to place specific items to specific locations in your backback to grab a bonus from them and it is really relaxing. In some situations I really spent some time organizing my backpack in order to take advantage of rare items.

[b]Areas for Improvement:[/b]
- I hope to see more weapons and customizations for weapons/armors in the future. And there is no motivation to play with different builds.
- Over time, the game can become easier, especially when you become very powerful. It could use some tweaks to keep it challenging. There might be more levels and different enemy types that will surprise us.
- The game could benefit from more events to keep players engaged for longer.


[h3]Overall, I had fun playing this game and appreciate the work and creativity of the developers. I'm looking forward to more improvement in future updates and the game's full release.[/h3]

148468934.review:
One of the first Kickstarter projects I ever backed. They had a working demo of the dungeon crawling section, before they even started the kickstarter I believe, which hooked me. The core of the game involves turn based combat by using items in your backpack. Your backpack has slots, similar to diablo and other item management games, that you can increase as you level up. From swords to bows, consumables and shields, and many many other items you will find plenty to aid you in your descent. 

The developers have been very transparent about their successes, set-backs, and all their updates. They've pushed back some much wanted updates but still gave us smaller updates until the larger one was ready. 

They recently, as of this review, updated the public test version to include the story mode. It already has plenty of content and gives you reasons to keep exploring the dungeons. You start simple, in a mostly desolated town, and slowly unlock more items, build more buildings, and eventually rebuild the entire town. 

Each run in a quick game can go great or terrible, all depending on what items you are able to choose from each battle, chest, random event, and stores. With so many items it is a fun time trying to find good synergies between them all.

Story mode lets you only choose from a small selection of items that slowly expands as you research more items, do quests, and build up your town. 

Try out the demo for a good taste of the dungeon crawling. The full version already includes much more, with more to come.

147432586.review:
200 hours spent, I absolutely recommend this nifty treasure.
The concept is new and fun. You puzzle your way through a ton of items, trying to fit the right setup into your bag. There are countless ways to earn the cheese you so desperately yearn for!

Many people scrutinise the design for being too constricting. I do not agree with that. Yes, you work towards to find your build and you will stick with it for the rest of the run. This is the goal of the game, It is like complaining that football is nothing more than 22 idiots trying to kick a ball into a square. 

Caveat:
I do agree though that the hazard system is unnecessary and forced. I just click somewhere to place "honey", "ice", and whatever I didn't read, somewhere on my inventory. I always brute force through it and after the fight the "hazards" disappear.
The "curse" mechanic got a little better but still has a "why?" hanging over it. At the beginning it was great. A curse was something terrible, something that influenced your whole run, As of later versions, curses became a nuisance, something to sigh at if encountered. It is something I accommodate, rather adjust to. "Today it is quite cold. Bummer" instead of "If you go outside you'll literally freeze!"

Conclusion:
I had a ton of fun just playing with "Purse" alone, and doing her challenges.
The game isn't perfect, there are some screws I'd like to adjust myself. Although, I think it is unfair to judge this is innovative team like this. It is whining on high levels. The game is awesome and should be celebrated for what it is, rather what others want it to be.

146750602.review:
This is a fascinating game that I would wholeheartedly recommend if the devs didn't keep releasing updates that make the game less fun.
RIP the version of the game before overheating was introduced.

EDIT: In the interest of clarity, my main issues with the game are mostly related to updates re-working things I thought were great the way they were (see the overheating mechanic - I used to have a lot of fun making the most broken circuits I could with the little robot guys, and the overheating mechanic in the latest update throws a frustrating wrench into it, if not making most of the stuff I found fun less viable).
Also, the re-working of relics has been kind of puzzling. Relics don't feel like substantial rewards much of the time now - I get that they're probably a godsend to people doing challenge runs, which is great, but I'm not always doing those, and honestly isn't that what the different game modes are for? 
Re-working so many of the items in one or two updates means that it's difficult and frustrating to pick up again after not playing for a while.

This could genuinely be (in large part) a case of me getting too attached to older versions of the game and not liking change. All in all, this game is still very impressive, and pretty fun, but it's not the game I sank hundreds of hours into, and that kind of sucks. The devs seem pretty committed to incorporating player feedback in a way that doesn't compromise their vision of the game, and that's pretty cool. 
As of the current update, I would recommend waiting to see if the game changes for the better before buying it.

Prior review:
I really don't know what happened to this game - around a year ago, it was in an amazing state; there was a lot of places that needed polish, sure, but the gameplay felt fun and balanced and with a decently interesting power curve - it just needed a few things like UI updates, achievements, maybe meaningful stats to track of an 'ascension' system beyond the 5-stack hard mode, and it would've been golden.

Instead, what's happened over the last year is a series of updates that seems to only create frustration. Runs used to be quick, focused, and enjoyable, and are now outright slogs with frustration mechanics that weigh you down and stop you dead in your tracks. Relics and other items that used to be good have been nerfed to oblivion or changed entirely. Mind you, I have played plenty of this game over the past year but each update, I play less and less and less until finally I barely want to play anymore at all.

To make matters worse, recent updates are incredibly bug-laden, in a way that's very noticeable and not enjoyable. I don't know what's driven some of the bad creative decisions and what's led to some of the rougher edges around the game, but it really wasn't in a bad state before, so it's very confusing. You won't have an awful time if the conceit seems interesting to you, but earlier versions were better, hands down.

That would be fine, but I don't find the playstyles of Tote, Pochette or CR-8 to be even near as enjoyable as the initial style with Purse. It annoys me to think how much more fleshed out the game would be had the development focused on one playstyle instead of multiple. Especially the variety with (usable) relics feels underwhelming.

At the moment it also doesn't really have much in the way of rewarding the player. There is very little feel of advancement, only checkmarks on challenges. Maybe in the future?..

That said, I do still enjoy the core gameplay loop a lot and find myself returning to the game time after time.

145832451.review:
It's probably a little overpriced. 

The game is a proper Roguelike, in that the only things you unlock that persist between runs are difficulty modifiers for later runs. There is an Atlas that logs everything you've seen, like in Gungeon; unlike in Gungeon, however, this logs literally EVERYTHING YOU SEE (as opposed to everything you pick up), so the Atlas fills up very quickly; this is just a consequence of how the game is set up, however, where you can freely decide not to stick with items you've picked up outside of battle.

There are five characters in Backpack Hero, each unlocked from the very start of the game:

A normal run of Backpack Hero with THE MOUSE has nine levels, unless you decide to enter Endless Mode, and games will generally last an hour or two at most if you're playing well. THE MOUSE is the most straightforward character, straight from the demo, and the only one I've beaten the game with. The other four characters are basically ideas the devs had that they tried their best to make work THE MOUSE's Backpack system. THE BIRD's gimmicks are "Pockets" (getting to build your bag with disjointed spaces at the cost of said pieces being mostly-useless shapes) and what amounts to a separate damage type that converts enemies to your side instead of killing them; countering both of these is that THE BIRD's gear sucks. THE FROG's gimmick is that most items are cards that you shuffle, draw, and discard "Slay-the-Spire"-style, with their Backpack being a playing field; the cost here is that the mechanics are a bit of a mess, that THE FROG gets less playing space through leveling up than basically everyone else, and that (like in "Slay-the-Spire") THE FROG cannot get rid of cards in their deck without paying. THE PORCUPINE's gimmick is that she gets Familiars who come with their own mini-Backpacks and can serve as meat-shields, countered by the Familiars being awful and your loot pools being polluted with stuff catered just to them. Lastly, THE ROBOT was some sort of attempt at a "build-a-circuit-for-Auto-Battling" idea I'm sure the devs got from another game; they just tried reworking him, possibly for the second or third time, and I've heard that he's still a broken hassle to use.

I wouldn't say the game scales particularly well; you'll either win or lose by Level 7 depending on what you have by Level 6, and that's in a game with 9 Levels. It's fairly charming, though, and some of the systems are pretty interesting. There are players far better than I, of course, who adore the game.

I'd say wait until it gets finished, but not recommending it feels unduly mean. x3

If someone asked me if I had any final words to say to my friends and family on my deathbed, it would be to play Backpack Hero.

145737719.review:
I want to enjoy this game, but it's become so broken and buggy that it's way too frustrating to play. Every run recently, I've given up prematurely because some combo piece I wanted to use simply refuses to work. What's the point of playing this kind of game when bugs prevent you from doing anything interesting? This doesn't seem to be a priority for the devs, who seem to be barreling towards a 1.0 release with their main focus being an ill-conceived story mode. I really hope they get a handle on things, because if they keep adding new stuff without fixing what's already there, the game will become unbearable to play.

RE: dev response

Bug reports for the items in question have already been submitted- CR-8's portal, black manastone, and any item that is moved after use (like the candle that destroys an item) being particularly annoying examples. Also, entire mechanics frequently fail to work, like pocket detection on Satchel, mana networks not connecting properly, CR-8's entire gimmick (not even counting the undocumented distance limit of charges), objects being moved or broken on save/load, items that rely on positioning (ie citrine) not being detected, etc. It's just reached a breaking point where the game doesn't even feel worth playing right now. I hope I'm proven wrong, but it feels like adding meta progression (something I actively dislike) and a story onto a game that is essentially a build sandbox is going to be much of an improvement. I really liked playing the game previously, and if the issues are all fixed then I'll enjoy playing it again- but right now, it's not in a state that I consider acceptable.

After trying the most recent update (which dropped later the day I wrote this review) in my first run I have run into a 0-use consumable which I believe had its charges used in a CR-8 test fire, as well as a burn-applying wand which consumed mana but did not actually apply the burn effect. This was before the 3rd floor.

Post 1.0 release: things are just as bad as they've always been, except there are brand-new systems which are also full of bugs. Even the dialogue has bugs, with missing translation string errors at key story points and even item descriptions, so you can't see what some items do. It's clear this update was rushed through the door to meet the Indie World deadline. Well, if you think getting a small surge of new players a little earlier than you otherwise would is worth giving them a bug-ridden experience, that's your decision to make.

What items, specifically aren't working for you? We'll make sure they're fixed in the next update!

Also I really hope story-mode isn't ill-conceived! Guess we'll know soon!

I've been playing and following this game for a long time now, even before it was available on Steam.
When I first found out about the game, it was genuinely a lot of fun, and an interesting concept.
However over time, the game just gets constantly less fun with every update. Be it due to nerfs, fundamental changes to pre-existing mechanics/items, or additions of altogether more annoying mechanics. The game has just been constantly degrading in quality. Worse yet is the devs are often asking/listening for player feedback, yet seemingly always do the opposite of what players want, or making the problems they express experiencing even worse than they already were.
Though don't get me wrong, the devs [i]have[/i] made a few positive changes here or there but on a whole the game has only gotten worse, as much as it pains me to say so.
That's about all there is to say about it. I just hope the devs have the realization they need to actually make the improvements to their game that it deserves, because at it's core it's still an interesting game.
