145012077.review:
While I do recommend this game in the end, I think it's best to wait until it is a complete product before really messing with it if you want to avoid any small headaches. The Demo may also give a bit of a weird look at the game as a lot of stuff has changed between the time the demo was made and the making of this comment. I know I've only played 5 hours, so far, but I played the demo a bit before finally deciding to grab the game itself and my verdict is... It's good, but still very early.

The good parts of the game is the same you'll see in any other review: It's a very creative way of handling a dungeon crawling game with a lot of different ways you can go through the world. Variety is the spice of the game for sure, because each character plays notably differently and there are various types of builds you can do with the Dungeon itself even having variety to it with typically two different location for each floor. Which is neat, though the enemy variety is rather low despite this, but that's probably for the best. Some types, like a rogue rat that shoots multiple times or a fire breathing salamander, can get really annoying.

The overall Gameplay Loop is nice and easy to understand. Organize your backpack, click on items in backpack to use them, and go through the game trying to not die from overload and from the people trying to kill you for some reason. It is odd there's not that many real "monsters", but that's another topic. Either way, the big issue with the backpack theme is mostly a lack of quality of life options. 

For example: There is an item called a satchel, not to be confused with the character named Satchel, which you can open and items inside with the only negative being that you can't open it during combat to use them. Which is fair and very helpful, but... opening it opens a small square space to show the squares inside that satchel space and it goes over whatever was under the actual satchel item in your main backpack and you can't move it, so you have to close it, move the item itself, then open it again. This happens a lot more with the character that has pets with their own inventory too and it's a minor thing, but really throws off your groove, y'know? It'd be nice to just move the opened square, but no area I clicked seemed to help.

This sort of stuff is what the game is lacking so far, which is good despite being a negative, as I didn't really run into any major bugs except some text appearing over other text boxes; like your energy number appearing above a speech box. There are also some items with text that I just don't understand or misunderstood, but they are few and far between. 

For my big negatives of this game, it has a far too high difficulty spike, a lack of any real things to unlock, and there isn't many ways to properly fix your build up. In order to use arrows for example, you have to have a bow, even if it doesn't say as much, and I've gone like six floors without seeing a single bow, but several types of arrows. Sometimes that's just how it is and I get it, but it'd be nice to have the merchants at least have an option for one specific type of item when you visit them for the first time. Somethin' simple.

The difficulty spike is what really hurts the game for me, though. I can adapt to having bad luck with items, but it feels that many enemies you fight get stronger as the fight goes on, even if it's their fault. For example: there is a knight and priest combo I ran into where the knight kept throwing "Spikes" onto his allies and the priest kept healing. So if I hit them, I'd be hurt and they'd just heal. Which is normal and the Spikes started low at just 4 a turn, and they die off quick every turn anyways, while the healing was at 20. It'd take awhile, but I'd win with that pattern as I could block the spikes when I smacked them, then block their attacks.

... And then the Spikes shot up to 7... and then 14, after just a 5-6 turns. The healing also shot up to 25-30 and they were gaining at least 20 armor per turn as well. I was hitting for maybe 10-16 per hit with what I had in my pack, but I couldn't block all those spikes and attack comfortably anymore. It quickly turned into nothing but a death wall, since there's no way to run, and that really hurt the experience for me. They weren't even a boss; just a regular chump in the dungeon. I'll get 'em next time, though.

Overall! I can only really rate this game as "It's early access." It's going to have issues and the devs seem very responsive to criticism, as long as you're not being a chump about it yourself. They have unique ideas, the characters are all interesting, and I appreciate the costumes they have too, though I feel those should be things you have to unlock at least. Really helps in Rogue-Likes to have a type of goal, y'know?

Either way, I recommend the game if it sounds fun. If nothing else, it's not demanding much from you except your brain power, so it's a go-to game for on the go or just to relax with. Hope you enjoy. (' ')/

[Edit: I've added this part forward for the 1.0 Update as it's now out of Early Access!]

Including the stuff I've said above, the game hasn't truly changed that much from when I first reviewed it and its full release. Excluding, of course, the new "Story" mode that includes a lot of unlockable features that were mostly available during the Early Access Quick Play. Which is still a thing you can do anyways in the full game, as a nice feature. 

I have yet to beat the Story Mode as of the time of this review, but it's neat so far. It revolves around creating and upgrading a new town near the Dungeon after finding out that Purse's mother was lost within. Magic Backpack in hand, Purse is dedicated to finding out the truth /and/ making a place for everyone to live comfortably. The story itself isn't bad, but that's about as much as I'll say. You'll have to dig deep in the pack to find the truth~!

The Story Mode Gameplay is where the new form shines, as it does address my issue with the game not having much to unlock- now a massive amount of items that are either new, or are in Quick Play, are something you can unlock. The way you unlock them is by first building something related to them, such as a Blacksmith or a Magic Shop, and then using items from the dungeon to research this new item. It's a very smart way to add even more variety to the game as now you'll have to build your runs around what you want to take back, too; sometimes you'll /have/ to hold onto that Shuriken so you can research new Shuriken at home.

There are also various people in your village that give you quests, unlocking more items by going on unique runs. Some runs make you just do the default stuff, but there were others that required you to use a bow, or one that had me use a fish-stick powered up by other fish. It was neat and allows for different ways of playing, as you can redo those quests anytime you want, though for no real reward after the first time. Still, unlocking the new features may lead to even more ways to start standard runs... such as getting access to the other characters through their own quests. I won't spoil how you do so, but it is neat that each character seems to have their own set of quests too; I'm only dreading the robot's quests...

Regardless, my opinion on this game has only improved, although it seems the difficulty curve still has trouble; I've had plenty of runs where numbers suddenly just skyrocket and I'm left going "Well, heck, I didn't have a miracle in my pack!" There's always next run of course, but I can see it being frustrating when you're near the end. At least dying lets you take one item back for free... though the mail-mole is probably better. Shame you can't carry a pocket one around~

143109941.review:
It's an interesting concept and I absolutely love the ingenuity involved in having to use your organizational skills to your benefit and the music is amazing, but the one problem I'll always have with modern roguelikes (which they call rogue-lites) is the expectation of death. A properly-designed game with an endless mode would theoretically allow you to go indefinitely if you play your cards right, whereas in this game if you survive long enough it invariably ends up throwing fights at you that are completely impossible for you to win.

I'd love to recommend this to people, but in its current state there's just way too much RNG involved in surviving beyond the first iteration, and to me, the game shouldn't have an endless mode if it's going to eventually throw a tantrum and go the "rocks fall, everyone dies" approach by throwing an impassible battle at you. 

If they rework endless mode, I'll happily come back and change my rating.

142921367.review:
Yes, but rather than a 90% that it is in userscores right now, it is more like a 70%. Otherwise, from time alone, if you want to clear every character at least once on standard you will get enough playtime out of it to justify the purchase.

[u] [b] The positive points: [/b] [/u]

- Some characters are super fun and very well thought out in how different they function and what combinations they can go for. Really different playstyles that also do make inventory management meaningful, on top of what kind of damage (flat, projectile, magic, spike/defensive, poison etc) you are going for. That tandem mechanic for characters like the Satchel and CR8 and Pochette are really interesting and fun to play around with...for a while.

- Items can be crafted on. I positively love this, having an item with a description so long that you need to scroll downward is 100% awesome, not just that, you can add crafting potential (albeit there is far too few points for that as of right now in the standard game) to add further possibilities all in the neverending search for that one completely broken build.

- The humour is great, every new enemy and every item is fun to find and it adds charm to the otherwise rather dull dungeoncrawl.

- It is still Early Access. A story is supposed to get added which is nice and a certain hope for awesome is always there when it comes to Early Access passion projects which this certainly seems to be


[u] [b] What holds it back: [/b] [/u]

- There is nothing that binds it all together, everything seems kinda fragmented, you never get the feeling that you are doing something of worth with an impact for further runs. It´s not just a story, it could be starting stats for characters that you could have to work for. Or certain permanent itemupgrades or pathways or...but literally not even the settings selections stick until the next session. 

- Why the above point is hurting gameplay fun for me is bound to how the game is set up. You play a tutorial, which is basically the whole game. And then you can select some other "gamemodes" which is basically mostly gimmick changes like "hard mode" which is just some modifiers to our health and the enemies. Or limitations to the backpack spaces available. No doubt, those are extra challenges. But basically it suffers from all roguelites extra challenge modes...of course you can make everything so difficult that nobody can clear it anymore UNLESS you get that one perfect run finding all the perfect items and getting the perfect combination of enemies and...yeah well for the majority of players, myself included, that is simply not fun. I am playing exactly to make builds and explore synergies...so then you go the other direction: you pick "endless dream" which gets rid of status effects and gives endless forge potential. That is nice. But the thing about endless is...you don´t have endless backpack space. Infact, in endless you do the same thing that you do in normal standard games that go on endlessly: Yes, you die slower, but you just wait it out until the enemies become unbeatable. That´s it. That´s all there is to endlessmode. You wait until it is over. 
So you can go the one direction: Make the game "harder" which is mostly just hinging on luck at some point.
Or you can go the other direction: Make the game easier and wait until you have to fight an enemy you can´t beat, no matter the struggle.
This is not Slay the Spire. You do not get to make infinite-turn one-break the game-synergies. You have limited amounts of space, limited amounts of gold to craft, limited lifepool...you will get overwhelmed no matter what. So there really is no real point to endless mode. And standard mode ends quick, it´s like 9 floors, barely enough to enjoy a build once it comes together. It feels like only 50% of the standard game is done yet. There is just not enough content for anyone but the first character. Everything else feels like: Yeah we don´t know how to go on with this system so lets just create a new mode or a new character. And with everyone of them it feels like: Yes, this was nice, where´s the rest of the run? No, not endless, the rest of the actual thought out content? Oh its not there, well, early access I guess. But its still unsatisfying. Every end of a run feels like you just started working something out and then its over and there is no point to it either, you experienced it and thats about as good as it gets. Rarely will I go back to do a strategy just because I think I could do better. I played it once and that´s how good it gets honestly...and do I play another strategy? Eh, not really, most of the time. It´s not like you have endless combinations but every character has like 3 different ways that are viable for it, so usually if I like playing two different ways on a character, then I play two rounds of the character, both of which felt had an unsatisfying ending and then that´s it. Kinda meh. 

- There are many combinations of items and spaces than can get you do win a run. But you basically will never do anything that feels like "I outsmarted the game". Mostly its just, I found an item that adds atk per adjacent gem. So you search gems. That´s not really clever. It´s a winning strategy, but its not really anything more than that, everyone deciding to build around that item will build the exact same way with more or less tactics and luck in finding them. Everything else works the same way usually. It´s not like different items really work together, they just stack. You don´t multiply poison stacks, you just add. You don´t trigger them early. You just wait your turn. You don´t change poison stacks to something else, you just wait it out. You never will do something special honestly, if you use an item wrong, well then you don´t win. Its not like you stumble into a hidden strategy. You do what the item says, the better a player you are the better you make use of it. It works, but its not Slay the Spire openness to build ideas.

- You can get simply stuck on enemies. Approaching the final boss with full health would suggest that you are ready for it, if you play well then that has to be the case, right? No. You can do fine against everything else and then, because there is no free gameplay but only inventory handling, you can play as well as you like against a boss and literally have no way of winning basically losing you the run by default. That should never be the case and yet it happens frequently, clearing everything with full life should give an indication about your powerlevel and not completely randomly stop working regardless of gameplay.

- Character strength is unbalanced. Tote is literally just less fun than all other characters. His kit doesn´t allow for great combos. There is no way to get rid of unnecessary carvings. It is hard to cycle through them as well. 

- Bugs bugs bugs. Sometimes selected curses can not be removed from the deck. Sometimes inventory spaces get stuck behind the backpack. Sometimes items get locked in the selection area. Sometimes an item gets used in an infinity loop etc etc. That being said...

- It is early access. And I surely hope they do not go the Brotato or Peglin route: "Just add more stuff on top, just stack it and that makes it more interesting". Those other two I gave a negative review for that reason. Here I hope that most of what those negative aspects are will get fixed with a storymode being added and the game taking actual shape from there. I have that hope. And I do have like 10 hours of fun gameplay for 10 bucks which is making it worth it already. But its nothing more as of yet. A cool concept with many different stacking mechanics. But very little synergy and very little reason for exploration. And those aspects would be what would make it a 90%er for me.

142896364.review: Backpack hero was my "love at first sight" game. From it's gorgeous pixelated artstyle to it's wide array of challenges, scenarios, and characters, it has nearly everything i could ask for in an early-access rougelike. It has a Slay the Spire- inspired combat system (i.e. some items give block, others do damage, poison and other status effects decrease by one each turn, Enemy behaviors are show over their heads, energy limits what you can do in a turn, ect.), and that works really well for the game, because while i genuinely loved slay the spire, at times it felt like my build would stagnate, and i would just hit a progression wall and slowly lose the run from there. backpack hero's leveling system means that even if you're happy with how your inventory is arranged, you can squeeze in a few more accessories to make things easier. and those small expansions really pile on well during a run. My one small annoyance is that, at a certain point, looping just becomes impossible. I would love for a mode specifically designed for you backpack to get as big as possible, maybe something like Double experience, or even a mode where experience scales with your floor number, and unlimited backpack expansion. but otherwise, backpack hero is amazing, and it is a joy to play.

142768266.review:
Embark on a Fun and Charming Adventure!
*Bursting with adorable graphics and a delightful storyline, Backpack Hero on Steam is the perfect game for those seeking an exploration adventure filled with whimsy, humor, and unbounded joy.

A Unique and Engaging Experience
Backpack Hero is a game like no other, combining elements of exploration, puzzle-solving, and RPG gameplay. The adorable backpack-wearing protagonist, Matti, ventures through a charming and interactive 2D world, which is full of secrets and missions that uncover even more secrets.

Charming Graphics and Visuals
The delightful graphics of Backpack Hero feature stunning and colorful environments. The 2D world is meticulously created, dazzling with gorgeous colors and bright, inviting visuals. The character design is equally stunning, with Matti being especially memorable, cute, and likable.

Fun-Filled Gameplay
Backpack Hero offers a rewarding gameplay experience, where you can collect hidden items, complete challenges, and enjoy engaging combat against lovable enemies. The puzzles that pop up throughout the game can be challenging, but they are always rewarding. The game becomes progressively harder as you advance, ensuring that it remains fun and challenging.

Immersive Soundtrack
The music is a standout feature in Backpack Hero. The charming and immersive soundtrack is incredibly catchy and will have you humming the tunes long after you're done playing. The sound effects add to the overall experience, with each action providing a satisfying and enjoyable sound effect.

Replayability and Endless Fun
Backpack Hero is a game that you can play over and over again. With so many secrets to uncover, items to find, and levels to complete, the replay value of this game is incredibly high. The feeling of satisfaction when you find hidden special items after a difficult puzzle is pure enjoyment.

Conclusion
In conclusion, Backpack Hero is a unique and delightful game full of engaging gameplay and a charming storyline. With its stunning graphics, fun-filled combat, and immersive soundtrack, this game is perfect for those who love action-exploration games. Do yourself a favor and join Matti on his quests through a world that's both charming and poetic. You won't regret the incredible journey that is Backpack Hero.

Challenging Game, requiring you to figure out good Synergy for your Accessories and Weapons. I got stuck on one of the Bosses for awhile because I didn't heal very much during the Adventure and ran out of Turns to Guard during that Fight. Eventually, I had to take a step back and reorganize the Pack into a slightly more Efficient Setup to Maximize my Damage Output. I went back and got that Victory, only to realize even more Dungeons lie ahead.

The Bosses can get difficult and there is no certainty in "Going Back" for Heals or Consumable Items, but that ultimately means one has to carefully budget their Resources or risk a failed Expedition when the Boss shows up.

Overall, very enjoyable.

142384748.review: The phrase "A Roguelike inventory-management game" may not sound very interesting but it actually is. It's a take on the Roguelike genre formula that I haven't seen before, and it actually works. As with all Roguelikes, RNG can make or break a run so some attempts will go well and others will not. Fortunately there are multiple characters to choose from and they significantly change the way the game plays so if something isn't working you can pick a different character and try another approach. This gives the game more replay-ability than might be obvious at first glance.

142323513.review: Backpack Hero is a roguelike dungeon crawler with lots of random item drops and an emphasis on inventory management. It’s easy to pick up and play thanks to a short and sweet tutorial and has lots of potential. The early access version I played was stable and polished. Looking forward to where the devs take this one.

142242839.review:
Just to note, this is a Early Access review. So this is just my feelings on how the game is thus far.

The game is great, your character (there are several to choose from) is moving around a dungeon via a map at the top of the screen. You encounter events, npcs, and loot galore. The whole game revolves around your Backpack ala the title of the game. It has a limited amount of spots (Think of a grid based inventory system). 

Think of the items in your backpack as equipped on your character as they act like that. Everything in your pack can either be used or modifies other items inside of it or affects you directly. If you want to attack you have to use an item in your Backpack to do so. And doing so costs energy of which you usually start with 3. You can choose to attack 3 times with a 1 energy weapon or attack twice and defend with your shield once, increasing your block by X amount. There are a lot of other items that can be interacted with within the backpack to crease a lot of innovative and crazy combinations during the game not just attacking and defending.

The game lacks a bit in the visual and audio departments. While the characters look great and I enjoy the designs of them all. The backgrounds for the different areas are very basic, with all of them being wall with a few hints of what area you are currently in. Like the starting area is a stone brick wall, and the next area is a stone brick wall with a few vines, and the next area is a stone brick wall with some ice. Some more detailed backgrounds for the general roaming, and specific backgrounds when you enter a shop, or encounter certain npcs or areas would be amazing to see.

Audio wise, the sound effects are fine, they are basic, but get the point across And while I hope that every weapon would get their own sound, I know that will probably not happen, nor would I expect it to happen. That said. Musically, each area at least should get its own theme, same with different bosses and maybe even mini bosses. That is how I feel anyway. Right now its all the same music and I found myself turning off the music and throwing on my own as I played for any extended period of time.

142221217.review:
It's OK.  The concept is great.  And while there are some (much-discussed) annoying issues with the UI and with rules not working, it's Early Access, so that's not a deal-breaker.

The bigger issue is game balance and flow of play.  Of course, this is a lot like a deckbuilder; there are going to be stronger and weaker builds and demented combos; but it feels like you go to zero to 60 in one second and then up to about 300 the second after that.  In my last play, I happened to pick up two items in a row 1/3 of the way through that resulted in _literally_ no enemy getting a single turn for the rest of the game. 
 That's neat, but there doesn't seem to be much middle ground; either you have a build that obliterates things or you plink away slowly until hitting something that kills you.

At the same time, figuring out optimal item arrangements takes a lot longer than it feels like it should; part this is due to UI weaknesses, but part of this is also just because many of the strong strategies involve a lot of "these 8 items each give a bonus to adjacent items, but some apply diagonally and some don't, some of them limit which items receive the bonus, some give different bonuses to different types of items, some of them care about vertical or horizontal placement..." (and it doesn't help that some location-based effects, like mana conduction, don't work intuitively when you have, e.g., a diagonal item.)  I know this is sort of the point of the game; I just feel like there has to be a way to implement it that feels less twiddly while still incorporating all that optimizing, min-maxing goodness.

I don't think any of this is the result of poor design choices -- I think it sorts of comes with the nature of the mechanics.  And I think it's solvable, but it requires the game to bake in the oven for longer rather than hurtling towards a full release.  For that reason, and only that reason, I find it concerning that effort and attention is put into advertising plushies of its characters (real life ones for sale with real money) on the title screen, when both the central mechanics and the UI feel unbaked.  That feels a bit like the cart is being put ahead of the horse.  This game has great ideas and even some great components, but I am not optimistic that it's going to come together in a substantive way.  I do wish the devs good luck with it.

141363925.review:
Backpack Hero is a refreshing game that should be added to everyones list of go-to Roguelike games.

Although the game is far from perfect, the uniqueness of this game more than makes up for it. In this game, you control one of several characters with a backpack that can hold usable items, with each character having their own unique mechanics. The backpacks use an inventory system similar to PoE or Diablo where items take up a variable number of slots and you end up playing inventory jenga to best fit your entire build. Most items have some sort of incentivized placement; Some items do more when adjacent to other items, some need no items nearby for them to work, some items are "heavy" and can only be placed at the bottom of the bag or on top of other heavy items, and this list goes on and on. This simple concept is actually ridiculously fun, and adds a lot of build variety and freshness, since its a concept that is 100% original and unique. On top of this, the discord community is very active and the developer is very accepting of feedback from the playerbase; patch after patch, the game only seems to get better and the things that players complain the most about get fixed within a patch or two.

I will say that the game is quite hard at times. Sometimes, its really easy to just die because of bad item rolls. On top of this, as of writing, this game still doesn't really have a prestige system. The game does have gameplay modifiers which can act as a ascension system, but the difficulty related ones are more leaps rather than stepping stones that they are in most games. Overall, I still recommend playing this game if you enjoy puzzle and roguelike games, because it satisfies both quite well.

141105762.review:
[h1]Easily a recommended game[/h1]
[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*]If you like Rogue-like Deck-builders, such as Slay the Spire, then this game offers a great change of pace by including an inventory management mechanic.
[*]Loot Synergies are super satisfying and relics can completely change how the game is played.
[*]It easily has over a 100 hours of content, my first successful run took 5-7 hours.
[*]There are currently at least 5 different classes which each bring very different play styles.
[*]Different game modes that make runs easier or harder.
[*]Games still in early access.
[/list]

[b]Cons[/b] (At least in my experience with the Steam Deck)
[list]
[*]Occasional graphical issue: screen gets stuck in a dimmed state when swapping through differing menus.
[*]Controller Miss-Inputs: Menu will pop up with new inputs, but inputs will activate on the previous menu.
[*]There are some balancing issues, but I don't have enough playtime to justifiably confirm them.
[*]Dungeon road map could use more variety, each floor is basically a long path with 1-2 optional paths for loot/events. It'd be nice to have branching routes that give the option to spice up runs. It could give you more loot opportunities but at the price of harder encounters or maybe give up loot opportunities for a little bit of health or even an easier route, etc.
[/list]

All in all, Backpack Hero is a great Rogue-like Deck-builder that brings a nice change to the formula. It's only in early access and it feels like it's just under a finished state, so I have high hopes for the future of this game. Sure there are some bugs and balancing issues, but other then that, it's hard to label this game as bad. I could easily play this for at least 100 hours on the Steam Deck.

141031983.review:
How to put this... Imagine you're playing Resident Evil. You come across a dinky little pistol that has a crappy damage value. You'd pass it by, right? 

Well, what if I were to tell you that, if you just put it diagonally across from this specific green herb, in your bag, it will gain a damage boost? What if you found a pistol that, when fired, also let you shoot the adjacent four pistols placed around it at the same time? What if you discovered a stun gun that got stronger with every battery you placed next to it in your bag?

Backpack Hero is a wonderful, spacial sorting challenge for the OCD gamers out there. Once you understand the rules, and decide what kind of build you want to strive for, it all comes down to what items you find and how you expand your pack. On one run, I wanted to try a heavily armored build, but I ended up filling my bag with every Cleaver variety in the book, which surprisingly melted the bosses with the help of a chef's hat and some duct tape.

This is a charmingly silly, yet complex dungeon crawling game. Every item is relatively simple, but the combinations you can create can easily spiral wonderfully out of control. A fully-stuffed 10-pocket backpack out of 10. Get hoarding, pack rats!

140750274.review:
[b]TLDR: Great game in need of some TLC and a minor balance patch. Perfect for short (couple) hour long sessions.[/b]

I want to caveat this review by saying I adore this game, it's my go to I want to play for an hour or two but not all night and I frequently have more than one game running at a time. 

The game is brilliant in that you do legitimately have to think about how you want to approach an encounter, how you prioritise encounters on a floor. I like that sometimes you just have to accept being hit for 20 damage to survive the run and how that affects later choices. 

I really love the varied approached to a run and how one item frequently has the power to pivot the backpack. 

I have tried multiple bags from the mage doing a huge amount of damage in one turn but with little to no armour, I have played a tank who used a ton of haste and spikes to watch my enemies suicide onto me, and I have played almost everything in between. 

BUT.

This last update is a fairly large step back. I am not a fan of how the curses now work, and I'm also beginning to tire of a lot of the new items, which in my opinion aren't much better than the old items which mean they just take up loot drops and so slow down and make the game more difficult but not in a 'fun' way. 

I'm not sure exactly when this change happened but you now cannot forge certain items (and I'm not sure what specifically is the reason why some can or can't be) and the most frustrating thing is there isn't a tool tip advising you of this, so you can have a scenario similar to my last run: I needed a haste upgrade to stay alive, went to the forge and was 5 gold short, so I sold something only to go to the forge and discover I couldn't add haste to my shield anyway. 

I do thoroughly recommend the game but I would urge the developers to consider quality over quantity in the next update, there are plenty of items which do not see use, even in niche runs and the game is too difficult in it's current state to play with new builds.

140739413.review:
What an amazing game so far! This may be my favorite indie game of 2023!
I'm playing in Early Access mode and I'm blown away.

- The music is so amazing- and that's no small feat! It's not easy to come up with a sound track that isn't annoying after several hours of listening to the same thing, and they did it! I love the sound track so much and the sound design overall is great.

Though the game is still in early access, some little things things I would like to see:

- Upon death, an option to Load Game would be convenient

I love this game and can't wait to see how it continues to grow!

I would recommend this game to anybody who has a penchant for adventuring, item collecting, and crafting/tinkering.

A fantastic time with an engaging gameplay loop, and criminally adorable characters and npc's! Each run can provide completely alternate ways of playing, where every step and choice taken can severely impact your journey! 139991094.review:
After coming off an absolutely horrendous time trying out another deckbuilder "Wildfrost" (awful game btw) it's refreshing to play something in the genre that respects your time, and hasn't implemented ever mechanic in the most player hostile was imaginable.

While there are still some things Backpack Hero needs to improve on, specifically a tutorial or a more visually obvious way to explain how the Mana system works, it nails it in all the ways that matter. Despite not having a true tutorial, the game is surprisingly intuitive and does a good job at visually show a player how the different items in your Backpack effect the other's around it. The RNG keeps things feeling unique from run to run, but doesn't feel oppressive or unfair due to the sheer volume of items offered to you. When you die, 99% of the time you can see where you went wrong or why your build failed.

To sum it up, Backpack Hero has a real shot at being the next great Deckbuilding Roguelike, with a fresh spin on the formula and mechanics unique to the genre. Considering it's still in early access and the game already has the content volume of a full game, unless they make some seriously poor decision then it can only get better.

138097967.review:
Fun and addictive game, but in serious need of proper balance, especially when it comes to enemy scaling, boss summon, and the new hazards.

Enemies scale quickly and relentlessly during encounters, even when they're not being buffed by rage or haste. This essentially puts a time limit on encounters, and heavily encourages front-loaded builds. It's often not viable to try and rally back-and-forth with an enemy, when after several turns they're dealing 50% more damage than they were on the first turn, and suddenly you're spending all your energy on blocking.

Bosses will often summon 2-3 enemies, happening as frequently as every other turn, so in addition to their visible buffs, the aforementioned invisible scaling, and swarms of summoned enemies, it's often impossible to ever keep up with the damage needed to clear out the summons, while also still blocking, and maybe getting a hit in on the boss.

Hazards are in a poor state right now, and actively ruin the fun of the game. Energy is a precious commodity, so why is that when I spend energy to clear a hazard, I'm still being punished with damage/burn/poison/etc? It's often better to ignore hazards outright than spend energy to clear them, which once again promotes front-loaded builds. Hazards should either cause harm but cost no energy, or cost energy and cause no harm, and it should be the player's choice just like it was with curses before.

The developers should focus less on "700+ items!!!!!" and instead put that energy into balancing the game properly, and ensuring that existing items are actually viable to play. The game is in desperate need of more viable and varied builds, and really needs to tone back on the mid-encounter scaling to allow breathing room for slower, more balanced builds.

I'm really looking forward to future updates for this game!

138022088.review:
I want to start this off by saying I am a kickstarter backer for this game; my screen name is in the credits of this game and two item concepts of my design will be making it into the final game.

With that said: this game is very heavily work-in-progress. This is not to say that the game is bad. The game is good. But it has a whole lot of unrealized potential and missing features because it is in very heavy development, and as a result I feel like a lot of its negative reviews are unfair to the game and its developers, especially because of how much effort they put in to balancing the game *while they are making it*, which is needless to say a massive undertaking.

In particular, there are a few complaints I've seen I'd like to set straight.

The new curse system is far improved from the old one. When you are cursed, curses are a status effect that can be self-cleansed by any of the usual methods before the end of combat. At the end of combat, this status spawns a number of additional cursed items as loot. These cursed items are (usually) powerful items that have strong upsides, but also have notable drawbacks. The curse part comes in when you choose not to take them. In future combats, curses you have left behind take the place of new battle rewards, (but not chest drops or shop rewards, with the exception of the 'shops spawn instead of loot' challenge mode) and continue to do so until you cleanse the curses, allowing them to be left behind.

Other reviews would lead you to believe this is the only way to deal with curses, but that's not true. Random events that take items accept curses, and treat those curses as Common items (as far as I can tell) for the purposes of rarity. Rerolling loot deletes all curses currently following you. And last, but not least, you can straight up destroy cursed items via conventional means... and in fact, certain cursed items are actually good for destroying curses!

This system is a HUGE improvement from what it replaced; previously, when you were cursed, you'd get a 1x1, 1x2, or 2x2 token that you had to place into your bag or you'd take scaling damage based upon how many curses you'd skipped. Many of these curses could not be removed without far more limited cleansing and destruction effects (or using them and incurring steep drawbacks) and would destroy anything they were placed upon, and there was no counterplay to curses other than 'kill the enemy before it curses you'.

Hazards took the place of the old curses, and now they're temporary items that can be played on top of items in your bag, without destroying them. At the end of each combat, they are completely removed, but items completely covered by hazards are disabled, so watch out. Some of them are a smidge too brutal, but they're very new and still getting active balance passes.

My general advice to anyone looking at this game: If you don't mind rough edges and somewhat janky balancing in some cases, this game is great. If you're coming into this expecting a perfectly balanced, perfectly polished, finished experience, you won't find that here yet, and you shouldn't expect that. The game is Early Access, and unlike many other games, is *properly using* that label. Even in spite of all that, it is a fun game that I am more than getting my money's worth out of, even after paying extra through Kickstarter to support the developers and get my items added to the game.

137989564.review:
Dungeon crawler with kinda quirky mechanics. Your attacks and abilities are dictated by the objects in your inventory and how they are situated, almost a mix of Tetris and Darkest Dungeon. Difficulty feels fair too, ignore the cries of those unable to adapt.

Tips: 
- Keep a potion on you that rids status effects, it will also rid the curse debuff and prevent you getting a curse at the end of combat.
- Re-rolling your loot at the end of combat using a dice gets rid of the curses, provided you haven't kept the curse in your inventory.
- Just don't keep curses in your inventory unless you value their traits, its that simple. It's not that bad.

137813421.review: The game was pretty fun, and I was excited for the variation the new characters would add. but it's difficult to enjoy anything about the game in recent updates because of the curses and status effects enemies can put on you, Like if you don't one turn every battle you will lose out on battle rewards nearly permanently. and in terms of certain status effects you will hemorrhage health with your only recourse be lose health now or lose EVEN MORE HEALTH next turn. god help you if your run isn't going absolutely perfectly and you run into any enemy like this. I don't want to understate this, you'll be fighting a regular enemy and they can just PERMANENTLY CURSE YOU, there's rare curse removal items and you can remove curses at the healer but you only get to choose one thing at the healer so god help you if you're low on health. I've also been told you can avoid getting the curse by using an item to remove the curse status effect before the battle ends. but again this is just extremely punishing for no reason, I could understand curses being a thing in a challenge game mode but it just being retroactively added to everything is insane. Overall I feel it punishes you for playing the game with your only recourse be hope you find enough anti-curse items (which is impossible considering the frequency you are being cursed.) I wanted to have an open mind but the curse items you're forced to pick up aren't even "it's got side effects but it's still useful" it's things like "+1 dmg but you lose 1 health every turn" or "deals 10 dmg but inflicts 3 self damage and stops working" it's just a horrific side effect with a really lame positive effect. I think there's a fix for this beyond fully removing curses. like maybe making the cursed items down-sides disappear when you purify the curse? or putting the curses into their own game mode solely for the devs? just anything to make the curses feel like they aren't a detriment to the game as a whole. because as is, it stifles the creativity on display with the new characters, and i'm not really sure how it got past early testing.
137813421.developer_response: Hey, There are more ways to remove curses besides cleansing them! Any event that trades items will take curses, and any item that can destroy another item (such as dynamite, evil hand, mechanized toy and many more) can destroy a curse permanently. We are still adjusting the system and the balance of curses and hazards, we want to make sure they are engaging additions to the game!

137586586.review:
Backpack Hero is an incredible indie game, given great dedication, care and passion by its developers. The game is filled to the brim with interesting and fun characters, a unique combat system, intuitive inventory management and cute and expressive pixel art. It combines well-known tropes in both storytelling and game design, and gives it all its own unique spin. You could describe the game as both incredibly easy to pick up and play, and incredibly complex to memorize and master.

The game involves you picking one of five main characters (currently), each with their own unique playstyle, and dropping into the first floor of a massive megadungeon, equipped with a kit that's unique to them and will be replaced, bit by bit over the course of your adventure. You can swap between setups or "builds" with only the items you have on hand and choose between a staggering amount of options, ranging from tiny multi-hit attacks to massive Berserker-like blows that get stronger over time, to a mage with a blazing staff that regenerates mana each turn, to pure defense that slowly takes down enemies through Spikes, a status that hurts enemies each time they strike you, or anything in between. A pacifist's build is possible as well, using the Charm status to turn enemies over to your side. All "builds" have their own strengths and weaknesses, and the synergy between each is only bound by your imagination; There's no class system stopping you from trying out anything and everything.

Yes, I am singing this game's praises, because I truly believe it deserves it. The care for this passion project is clear to see with every step you take in it. The developers spend plenty of time listening to and talking with the game's fanbase, gathering all kinds of feedback and working on bugs practically in real time. I love this indie adventure roguelike puzzle game, and as you can see by my hours logged here, I'll continue to love it... No matter how many bad reviews it receives.

Part of buying an early access game is inevitably seeing it change, as the developers experiment with the mechanics, items, structure and world. Items will be shifted, buffed and debuffed until they finally click into place. Entire mechanics will be changed, made more interactive, creative and hopefully intuitive as time goes on. By buying an early access game, you agree to support the developers with your purchase, with no promises of what the game turns out to be. You are effectively buying a demo, with the agreement that your money will be used to fund its improvement.

The game is being hate-bombed by players who somehow mistook this cute, relaxing puzzle game with great, harmonic music, a cheerful tone and fun mechanics for one that allows them to endlessly mash a button and watch pretty numbers go up, with no difficulty or depth of thought. You know the ones, they mash through a tutorial as fast as possible, refuse to read the game's text then blame the game for not telling them what to do or how to do it. This is not a game that lets you do that. You need to learn, adapt and exercise your brain muscles in order to get where you need to go. The game isn't hard to figure out by any means and the most it demands from you is math. If anything, the developers have created many modes and modifiers to fine-tune the game's difficulty to your liking, including some special modes. This game is accessible and thoughtful in its implementation. It is not, however, mindless. It is, in the end, a puzzle game. So if you also like creative puzzle games and grid-based inventory systems, please give this one a try. It goes on sale fairly consistently and I'll happily vouch for it; It's worth the money by far.

I, for one, am very excited to see how they add to the world presented here. I hear they're planning to add an entire town outside of the main gameplay loop eventually, and I can't wait to see it come to life.

137516475.review:
With the revision to the curse system that was implemented in a recent patch, and more testing done with the hazard system (admitedly, before the revisions I was under the assumption that hazards remained in the inventory past battles, but this is incorrect.) As it stands the hazard system seems fairly comfortable to play with and poses a secondary challenge of items being blocked, or debuffs applied to the player. I still think fire cascading out of control is a bit strong, but the rest seem interesting and a fun challenge, such as smoke flooding your inventory and fading away after a few turns. maybe if the fire had a decay on it, being able to propagate X number of times before it turns into a smoke hazard and goes on from there. Perhaps if the lightning debuf did a similar thing, creating a fire hazard instead of generating more lightning below it. Self damage isn't bad, but when you have large scale inventories it poses a real risk, but again that's half the fun of the game.

Since the curse system (my biggest issue within recent updates) has been adjusted and seems much more friendly (despite it being a hindrance), the game is very good, it might a bit more QA testing for each update, but I would otherwise recommend it

[strike]Update after update, this game looks more and more fun to play, over 700 items to mess around with, But all I get are curses. The newest Hazard/Curse mechanic is just... bad. If you get one curse, you're stuck with that item until you get lucky and get a rare item that can cleanse an item, but only if that item is in your inventory, and even then it's only ONE item, which is compeltely useless when you run in enemy after enemy after enemy after enemy that applies multiple curses to you. Keep in mind this is -after- a hotfix that made it so enemies won't try to curse you if you're already cursed, but they still do. 

I really want to like this game, I really do, but with every update changing core mechanics, it goes from a comfy cozy RPG inventory management game, to a damn race against time and praying you get an item that clears status effects (positive and negative), or just hope you can get strong enough before every. single. item, gets replaced with cursed items, that don't go away until you can either fit them in your inventory and get a random lucky decursing item, or pray you can beat the boss with your whimpy gear and get cleansed by the healer at the end of it all (if you have enough money that is).

I can't in good faith give this game a positive review until after an update that fixes or makes these curses not nearly as bad. I preferred the old curse system over this one, and the new hazards are interesting but they escalate and get out of hand WAY to fast. There's one that adds a fire item to your inventory, which spreads to adjacent spaces, which then doubles, quadruples, octuple, and so on, until your inventory is full. The only upside is that they're free to 'clear', but they give 2 burn to you. Unless you can clear any buffs you have, you're absolutely screwed if you don't win immediately after clearing the fires. Oh and did I mention that they dissable anything their ontop of until you clear them? Good luck using your weapons when fire spreads over it every time you clear it each turn[/strike]

Very fun, quick game, where You take control of a rat (or something later on) that has a stretchable backpack on it's back. Everytime You level up, backpack gets bigger. Like in other roguelikes of this type, the core of fun is to assemble good combination of items from those given to You from chests / battles and events. The better synergy, the better results. Enemies will rarely surprise You, so it all depends on your item management and luck of getting those.

Pros:
+ Inventory management
+ Decision making
+ Perfect short game
+ Each character has it's own gimmick
+ Multiple ways to play it
+ Save / load function
+ A lot of status effects
+ Friendly towards the player
+ Challenges

Cons:
- No achievements yet?
- UI could get slight polish
- Curses are confusing
- Early Access

If You like Rougelites and need a quick one, this is the one to go. It's price could be like 10%, 15% lower for what we get but, doesn't really matter.

A shining example of early access. Pre-launched with a fully functional Itich.io game that could have been a product in itself, had a huge expansion for early access and has continued to expand and refine since then, with a loads of active development and communication with the community the developer has gone as far as to scrap mostly finished systems that just weren't fun.

All That said the game is massive fun even as unfinished as it is and promises only to get better with time.

136990154.review:
I find this to be a very enjoyable game with immense replay value. Inventory management to find new and creative ways to make some insanely powerful builds keeps things fresh.

However, I do take issue with the insane difficulty spike after completing a run and choosing to continue on Endless. Enemies begin to get exponentially more powerful each floor you progress, and the experience you gain does not increase with it, which will very quickly leave your once-powerful build nearly powerless. Have an amazing armor-oriented build with some insane armor buildup with spikes to deal with those stronger enemies, not only through spikes and haste, but also your weapon, which deals more damage the more armor you have in your backpack owing to having two pairs of those boots with that effect on your weapon? Before long, you'll deal with enemies who will apply a stack of 20+ poison on you every few turns, paired with another enemy who inflicts you with a similar stack of Weak, rendering you unable to protect yourself from damage and unable to deal damage. And if not poison, then large stacks of Rage being applied to 4+ enemies at once, who often hit twice, every few turns.

This difficulty spike really begins to kick in by the time you defeat the first boss in the 2nd loop (essentially the 4th boss). I can deal with this, sure, but if you want to see how far you can go... well, good luck. Furthest I've ever gone was floor 18 (6th boss, would finish the 2nd loop), and I couldn't beat it no matter what I tried. 

I'll keep playing the game, I love it, I just think the difficulty curve is WAY too sharp. I hope that changes with the full release.

This game is awesome.
Playing through the tutorial and even my first completion as the default character, I thought the game was simple but charming and enjoyable.

So I moved onto the second character, Tote. I didn't like this character and how they played at first. It was a huge change of pace and seemed like a mix between this game and Slay the Spire and it wasn't explained. Then I kept going and decided to beat it with Tote. I started realizing that it was less Backpack Hero and Slay the Spire and more like a marriage between Slay the Spire and Tetris, with Backpack Hero's inventory system as a small mechanic of the whole. I found some cool ways to break the game.

So I moved on to the third character, after winning with Tote. CR-8. Again, the mechanics made this feel like an entirely different game. In a great way. At first it felt like a weird change of pace from Tote, but there are so many ways to break the systems in this game and each character has unique mechanics.

There is a lot under the hood here, and I feel like an optimized run is difficult to identify.

I don't know if this game is for everyone, but it is certainly for me.

136512360.review:
One of the best roguelikes I've played in a decade.

On the surface, I thought this would be a game about inventory space management. However, it's a lot deeper than that.

Items have a lot of synergies, so it's not about if it fits in your backpack, but [b]where[/b] it fits. For example, helmets have to be on the top row or it becomes useless, some items must be chained with conducting items to buff a bigger amount of gear, and so on.

Two days in a row, I didn't realize it was 3AM because I wanted to play one more floor.

I don't know if it's too easy in the long run until I play more. But I didn't expect to reach floor 15 with Pochette on my second run with her (first run was just a couple of rooms to get a feel for the character).

EDIT: Seems that the developer is listening to the feedback on the curse system and is taking steps to make it more palatable. I just did a quick run with the new update and was happy with how they've adjusted the new curse system. I'm reverting my recommendation back to thumbs up now.

EDIT: With the most recent update and the addition of the new curse system, I have to revise my review. What was once a relaxing game that I spent almost 200 hours playing has become a tedious chore that I no longer enjoy. The new curse system isn't explained very well and adds nothing but a layer of frustration to the game. I went from completely loving the game to hating it. 

Original review: Love it, love it, love it! I know it's still early access, but I really like what they've done with this game, so far. I haven't even played any of the other characters because I'm so in-love with Purse's mechanics! I really like "Endless Dream" mode and love to see how far I can make it. 

The interesting thing about this game, one that everyone is probably already aware of, is that it's not only about packing things in your backpack so that everything fits snugly. No, there's also positives and negatives to take into account for each item, too! Want to be an archer? Well, arrows do more damage the more empty spaces to the right of them. So, if you're a pack-rat, you won't do a whole lot of damage as an archer! There's gems in the game that give you extra energy or more damage! But, sometimes they have quirks that make it so you can't have anything in the diagonal spaces around the gem, or you lose energy or take damage each turn! I love how almost every item makes you think about the positves and negatives and if you really want that extra damage at the expense of something else. 

All in all, this is a charming game. Fun graphics, fun mechanics. I can't wait for full release!

135819779.review:
This is a good concept, it is fun and has potential, I enjoyed the concept of it.

C-

However: a lot of things simply don't work, or are pointless. It feels like an incomplete game.

The GUI for controller support is very bad. the green button feels like it should cancel a selection in most of the screen choices but instead it leaves encounters causing the player to end them and leave opportunities behind.

There are a lot of neat concepts in the game, like projectiles, bows, magic, mana, conductivity and a few others, but because of RNG drops the player never really gets the chance to use anything but the sword and shield they start with.  You'll need an item combo, like mana battery or two plus a wand etc. to make magic items work, but you can't get them all at once, and inert, they occupy space in the bag that has armor and weapons in it keeping you alive. 

You don't have the space to keep things you aren't using, so you have to just walk past items that combine for different builds all the time and are generally stuck with the sword and board build.

A lot of items are just trash as well, self damaging, one use, etc. not worth the space in the bag.

The game needs GUI improvement, the bag in a bag is really hard to use for example and for some inexplicable reason, when you upgrade your gear the smiths take it out of your pack, if you continue without putting it back in you leave it behind and it is lost forever.

Generally a lot of tuning is needed for items, space and RNG drop mechanics.

I'll come back in May and see what they did.

135785467.review:
A BRILLIANTLY fun and unique concept. I knew this game was good when I became instantly addicted to it. 
This game mostly revolves around strategy and planning which are my favourite aspects of deckbuilders. There's a large variety of factors that go into building your backpack, and being able to find those synergies makes the game so satisfying after spending so much time organising everything with the limited space you have.

As mentioned in another review, in endless mode it feels like you build your backpack to a point where you can't go much further with it and simply have to hope that it goes as far as possible whilst you repeat the same moves over and over until you die. The 'endless dream' mode allows you to continue improving your build and reach higher levels, but it doesn't change the gameplay of clicking the same buttons over and over again. I feel the limited bag space and the slow rate of level-ups contributes to this feeling as well. Also, unlike other deckbuilders like slay the spire, your available actions are largely not randomly determined, so pushing for higher levels can feel pretty repetitive.
Even though I love endless modes, I think this is something that has to be accepted (for now) and the game isn't designed to go forever (like most deckbuilders). There's a good variety of characters in the game and some interesting game modes between them, so there's plenty of good fun to get out of the game still.

As of this time of writing, I reckon the game would benefit from the addition of meta progression systems. Currently, you can unlock harder or alternate modes which is great (I even think more modes/characters should be locked from the start until you complete standard on the first character). 
I do believe they are adding a village for you to upgrade in the future, and I hope it'll add stuff that makes the runs more interesting.

135772651.review:
[b]Recommended Buy[/b]

[hr][/hr]

Backpack Hero - the nemesis of the OCD gamer.  As you strategically manage your inventory through rogue-lite dungeon after rogue-lite dungeon, you'll find a well balanced challenge along with various game play elements.

I spent the first ~20 hours playing the first character experimenting with various builds and enjoying the challenge.  Magic, melee, range, or various combinations thereof.  Thereafter, I spent the next 40-50 hours experimenting with the other classes the game has to offer.  They're all fun and provide the player with significantly different play styles that feel almost like a completely different game.

As of time of the review, I've played a little over 100 hours.  In terms of content, the game is worth every penny and should be in every rogue-lite lover's Steam Library.

135752988.review: This game is a delight. Highly recommended for fans of turn based roguelikes and spacial puzzles. It's kind of like if you took the inventory management aspect from dicey dungeons and made a whole game out of that. The core of the game is relatively simple, but there is quite a bit to unpack (if you will) as you try new item combos and characters. There are plenty of items and the characters add some interesting variety in play styles. I find the game to be a bit thinky at times (in a good way) as there are many cool decision points. I enjoy playing at a somewhat leisurely pace as I consider the possibilities for my build. If you like fiddling with spacial arrangements, optimizing synergies, and experimenting with various approaches to victory this is a great choice.

Listen up folks, because I've got a new hero in town, and it's not some fancy caped crusader with superpowers. Nope, it's just an average joe with a backpack, but trust me, this guy is a total badass.

Backpack Hero is like a combination of a puzzle game and a platformer, with a healthy dose of humor thrown in. You play as a dude with a backpack full of random stuff, and your mission is to navigate through various levels and obstacles using only the items in your trusty bag.

The game is hilarious, from the witty dialogue to the ridiculous situations you find yourself in. I mean, who knew that a plunger and a rubber chicken could be used to defeat evil villains? And the animation is top-notch too, with colorful and vibrant graphics that make the game even more fun to play.

"Backpack Hero" is a fantastic dungeon-crawler game that offers a variety of features that make it stand out from other games in the genre. One of the standout features of the game is the inventory management system. The game offers a comprehensive and intuitive inventory system that allows players to easily manage and use their vast collection of items.

Players can collect hundreds of rare items, each with unique effects that can be useful in various situations. The inventory system makes it easy to find and equip items, and players can even position items in specific places to maximize their benefits.

Overall, "Backpack Hero" is an excellent dungeon-crawler game that offers an intuitive inventory management system, varied enemy types, and randomly generated levels. Highly recommended for fans of the genre and anyone looking for a fun and engaging game on PC!

8\10

132959984.review:
I first played this game on my brother's laptop in the hospital. I played hard for about 2 months.
And now I bought it with my account and I'm playing it, but I suddenly thought I should leave a review, so I'm writing it. 
In the hope that the developers got inspiration from this review.

The backpack management feature wasn't novel, but it wasn't bad either.
However, the overall content feels unpolished, lacks volume, and is out of balance.
The balance issue between characters itself can also play a role in the difficulty mode, so it can be.

*The balance between the items is seriously bad, and because of this, the playstyle is generally similar despite the number of items varying somewhat.
If you have enough armor, pick up a decent weapon, and have a growth plan, the game is already over.

*There is also a problem that the performance and grade of the item are not properly proportioned.

*The problem is that the backpack is too large, so it can hardly make use of the feature of organizing space.
(There is a mod that limits backpacks, but it cannot be combined with other mods.)

* It is also a problem that the enemies do not have characteristics.
Except for the simple stat difference between the enemies encountered at the very beginning and the final boss, there is no difference that can be felt as unique in their behavior patterns.
Attack, Poison or Burn, Debuff, Defense, Summon, Buff.
All enemies move 'simply' with these as the main, and there is almost no gimmick unique to the enemy.
I can't even feel that the final boss has a gimmick...
It's very disappointing considering that Slay the Spire has all the enemies, elites, and bosses all with their own characteristics.
'Nemesis' 'Sentry' 'Chosen' etc. I hope you learn how many enemies behave with their own characteristics.
Since all the enemies in Backpack Hero are similar, the countermeasures also boil down to pursuing simple attack/defense power,
It's a big reason why my playstyle becomes similar every time.

* The type of gimmick of the item is lacking. Or, there are many items that cannot utilize gimmicks due to lack of performance.
This problem also, in most cases, is the cause of narrowing down the playstyle to simple attack/defense enhancement.

*In particular, I felt that the type of armor and gimmick were lacking. Armor, shoes, helmets, and gloves of decent performance.
It's all uncharacteristic, and it's the same in every game.
Why no capes, no belts, no shoulder guards?
These could give gamers a lot of options.
Armor, helmet, and shoes should be limited to wearing only one of each.
Instead, it would be nice to add socks or shirts so that these can be worn under armor or shoes.
Shoulder guards may be limited to those that must be adjacent to a type of armor or clothing. An item that can only be placed in the middle of a backpack would be fun.
A glove that provides an attack bonus or ignores weapon recoil damage when adjacent to a weapon.
A gas mask that provides no defense, but somewhat reduces poison.

*To counteract the fact that it is too easy to collect armor and weapons, it can be a good option to set durability on items.
It can be destroyed when used a certain number of times, or destroyed when hit a certain number of times.
It seems fun to have it destroyed only when it receives more than a certain amount of damage at once, destroyed when it takes damage from burns, or destroyed when it receives poison for more than a certain number of turns.
Setting the durability in this way also solves the problem that the backpack is too big because you need to have a spare item. Since you have to have a spare item, you will have to manage the space more efficiently. (Durability can be disabled in a space-restricted mode.)

*In addition, there are several game modes, but multiple selection is not possible.
Even the hardest mode is easy, so I want to mix something like 57 mode, but I can't..

I thought I could forgive all these flaws because it was an early access, but it was scheduled for an official release in April..
Can these problems be fixed in just two months? I'm not sure...

But I think this game has potential. Befitting the name ['Backpack' Hero], the feature of space management should be further emphasized. And if you give various gimmicks to the enemies, I think gamers will be able to enjoy it with a sense of tension every time.

*This is my personal complaint, the game is too slow. I'm not talking about computer specs. I would like to add a 10x or 100x speed option. (Like Slay the spire's super fast mod)
And I wish I could assign a hotkey to a specific item. I want to play at high speed by assigning f key to the wooden sword, d key to the shield, s key to the whetstone and the space key to end the turn.

*Is it possible to communicate with the development team via email? I don't use Discord or Twitter.

I have a good feeling about this game and I don't regret buying it at all. So, if the DLC comes out in the future, I will buy all of them. Because this game has plenty of potential for improvement.
Good luck with this game and its creators.

132530976.review:
SUMMARY: Backpack management was never so fun!  A sort-of-Roguelike game where managing your inventory is everything, with a cute aesthetic and a lot to make you think.  You also get into townbuilding, multiple characters and an actual plot!  It's not exactly a must-buy as you have to appreciate what it does, but it's very clever and accessible while leaning into its chosen mechanics.

You're a cute mouse in a world of cute animals - oppressed by an evil king who's obsessed with a local dungeon where your mom vanished.  With the help of a magic backpack you'll search for the truth, rebuild a town, make friends, and kill a LOT of bad guys.  Welcome to the world of Backpack Hero.

Backpack hero takes inventory management, most people's least favorite part of any game, and turns it into the cornerstone of an entire game.  Inventory management was sort of an annoying puzzle, Backpack hero asks "What if we made it fun?" then not only leans into it, but adds a bunch of other stuff besdies.

As any number of cute creatures with different abilities - from a big backpack to magical powers that create things to pets - you sally forth into dungeons to murder everything until you get to the end.  Most of the story centers around charming mouse adventuress Patch, but there's a Toad sorceress, a cool and suave avian bard, and more.

Inventory management/puzzle part is the OBVIOUS core of the game  Some equipment works better in certain positions or adjacent to other positions.  Magical powers manifest new things.  One character is a robot whose inventory is a rube goldberg machine inside of them.  The game turns into a mix of monster-mashing and optimizing arrangements - shades of puzzle and builder games.

The dungeon romp is more or less standard random-dungeon-and events.  Monsters are interesting and require tactical thought, and limited inventory pushes you to really make decisions.  Physical Space might be your biggest enemy . . .

Once you leave the dungeon, you get to help rebuild a town which has its own puzzle-like elements.  Resources you bring back help rebuild the town and you can unlock new buildings and options.  The town part is interesting and provides a plot, but at times is a little hard to manage due to the retro interface - and there is some grinding (but then again, hey, semi-Roguelike).

However the town and dungeon combine to give you a LOT to do.  Unlock new stuff.  Meet new characters you can also play.  Create an optimal town so you can unlock ALL the equipment.  If you're an unlocker/checklist type gamer, this is up your alley.

So is it worth it?  It's a great game, but it is a SPECIALIST game.  You have to really enjoy the inventory/puzzle mechanics and the townbuilding grind.  Therefore it's a game that EVOLVES mechanics, but you have to LIKE those mechanics.  If you don't want to calculate object placement and building locations, you're probably not going to enjoy it - which is fine.

So if you want to see Inventory HEAVILY re-imagined, then this game is 100% for you.  You probably already got it.  It's also a great gift to people who like Rogeulikes just in case.

It's also an example of why these experimental games matter, as it really dives into mechanical possibilities.

132512796.review:
For the time I have been playing this game, it has been one of my favorite roguelikes in the genre, but I doubt I would play much more than what I have played already. This comes from the game's lack of new content, which I feel could be improved. What I mean by this would be the pacing of new information to the player. It seems quite overwhelming towards the beginning, but underwhelming and overly easy after one understands every character's mechanics. My experience followed this path exactly, and as I reached the final boss of normal mode, it was very exciting to explore, but after I had completed that mode, the game seemed to pose no further obstacle other than player-induced challenges. 

A mechanic that outweighs this slightly would be the modifiers and mutations that one can apply to their runs at the start. However, this did not fix the issue, as, while the game was different in ways and enemies were more threatening, it never felt like I was facing a new or interesting challenge, instead having to adapt to more organizational and logic situations, which is not inherently a problem with game design. This leads into the main point I feel about this game. This game does not seem like it encourages failure much, instead being very forgiving in every gamemode. It seems as it was designed to almost be a sandbox logic puzzle, encouraging the player to find new ways to experiment on their own. I enjoy this aspect, and finding these new ways is invigorating, but unlike larger titles such as Slay the Spire, I feel as if I never get to use any skills or knowledge I gain while experimenting.

The biggest way I think that this issue could be fixed without change of the core mechanics of the game would be to simply restrain the player to limited items and characters until they unlock this content through reaching milestones. This would encourage a longer playthrough, and reward the player for getting further than required. I know a few friends that love this type of game, and just be able to sit experimenting at their leisure, but that sort of gameplay without proper pressure or difficulty puts me off about the game. 

Overall, this game was not what I expected, throwing much of what many other roguelikes include away, and for the time I was learning the basics of the game, and the time where the unknown was to be expected, it blew me away. I do not recommend buying if you want a similar experience to other popular titles (STS, BOR, HOF, DD, ATO, etc.). If it sounds fun to experiment without any limitation and create overpowered builds, definitely buy this game.

132464288.review:
Well, this one is a toughie.
On Backpack Hero, the player takes the role of one out of 5 cute animals adventuring into a dungeon equiped qith the basics and their magic backpack, which starts very small but gradually gets bigger as you level up.
Items in your backpack offer a series of benefits, either passive or active. A few of them are very simple (use energy, hit enemy) whereas others are designed to interact with adjacent items, or items in the same row/column, or some other idea.
What this means in terms of gameplay is that you have to be very careful when positioning new stuff in your backpack to get the most bang for your buck, as the space is limited and so is the energy per turn.
This system is both a blessing and a curse.
The good part is the catharsis that comes when you design the most efficient backpack possible and watch as every piece falls into place creating a beautiful cosmos of mechanics that let's you destroy rats in seconds.
The bad part is that, once you've reached that point, there's no reason to keep getting new items or touch anything unless some really good item comes your way. In practice, this means that there's a good chance that you'll be "done" when you're still half through a run, meaning that from that point onwards every fight will simply be a process of clicking things in order every single turn until death happens, which is not exactly engaging gameplay.
Now, the game let's you change things on the spot, but doing so consumes your turn (not exactly, but almost), and messing around with the backpack when you have 24 different all interacting with each other items can be a huge hassle.
The result is that you will spend a lot of time thinking things through for the first 4 to 6 stages and then just click away 'til the end, which is the exact opposite of how roguelite games usually work, and in my opinion not very engaging.

Also, and as a minor complaint, certain builds take so many items to start working that it's rarely worth the effort of saving up items just in case it ends up working in the end.

Still thumbs up because it is amazing game design at its core and I think it's absolutely worth exploring what else could this game offer.
