132445702.review:
Had to try the game myself to put a proper HONEST review. All these thousands of good reviews saying all these good things, I find it too good to be true and had my doubts. 

My review is about two paragraphs long. I highly suggest you read before you buy. Unless you don't mind spending $14 on sale or $17 to $19 full price. Depending on how high your state tax is. I honestly bought the game to see if the reviews were correct and the result, I'll just give a small sneak peak spoiler at the end of this review.


CHARACTERS (Thank you for adding 2 more characters, 3 is not enough)
Cute rat
Average looking frog (Can't tell their gender, I thought it was a boy)
"Robot" Tails, which I thought was cool
Woodpecker
Ferret or Chipmunk


WHAT IS THIS GAME LIKE?
This game is basically a kiddy version of "Final Fantasy" which I absolutely love. I honestly don't like the actual game, "Final Fantasy" even though I was born in 1991. When it comes to "Final Fantasy" I like to keep it 2005 or later. Like the gameplay of Kingdom Hearts or this game. VERY BASIC. Maybe I will enjoy "Final Fantasty" when I'm 45 or older. That game is too advanced and difficult. And the "Pokemon" random encounter spamming is actually very annoying.


DIFFICULTY
Analogy: It's not a easy true or false, it's more like a 8 multiple choice test. (Use your brain and THINK! I MEAN REALLY THINK! THINK HARD!)

This game is honestly very difficult at the very beginning but gets easier slowly when you collect more items. You can find 2, 3, or 4 monsters that can have a total of 2,3, or 4 attacks while you deal small damage to one monster. (you get stronger slowly later in the game with more items) I guess they did this so people wouldn't complain that the game will be too easy. This game requires you to think to win and I mean really think about your decisions to succeed. I died twice in tutorial. Which is really embarrassing and a shame since it's the TUTORIAL. But proves my point that the game is difficult.

AT THE BEGINNING OF THE GAME (BIGGEST FLAWS TO THIS GAME, FIX THIS PLEASE)
-The backpack is way too small (There was a lot of good gear that could've helped me but took way too many spaces)
-You do very little damage even after two rounds of collecting items. 1 on 1 monster, 1 on 2 monsters, easy
1 on 3, 1 on 4, 1 vs. a boss. (early game) WAY TOO DIFFICULT!
-There's no potions to heal. You gotta be really lucky to find some or make that decision to pick up a 4 space sideways staff that heals a itty bitty tiny bit of health. 4 spaces! Why not make a wand with 2 spaces? (Small Backpack problem)


OTHER THINGS
-very fast download which was very nice.

Floor, Experience, Gold, Stats, Save game, Options tab and map button could be 3 or 4 times bigger. My eyes are bad but not that bad (My glasses are up to date 2023 btw, so no, I don't need better glasses and I put it on full screen) the icons are tiny. 

Really cool arcade music. I have excellent hearing btw, and the music is LOUD, had to lower it in options

After every battle, click on the map on the far right corner and click a location. Otherwise you will wait forever and see your character bouncing up and down clueless. I was actually stuck for about 2 minutes waiting for something to happen.


CONCLUSION
I like the retro arcade graphics and music. Also feels like "Dungeons and Dragons." I will not refund this game. Although it can be very annoying being very challenging. (Means I need to take my time and really think with the battle decisions, really think hard, spend 4 to 7 minutes per battle to pick the perfect decisions)

And to answer the question about the reviews being right or wrong. Honestly depends on your skill. 
-If you are a person who's really smart and bright, is naturally highly skilled, and play "expert" or "hell mode" difficulty for the thrill and fun. As in the intense difficulty doesn't give you stress but makes you excited, the reviews are all correct.
OR
-If you are a person like me who is average or below average in intelligence, loves easy games even if it can be boring to win way too much, prefer easy or normal difficulty, or hard mode if I'm feeling dangerous. The reviews are wrong.

Feel free to comment or thrash talk, at least my review is 120% honest and legit.

132418357.review:
I often play roguelikes to relax. I find that the lack of permanent consequences and the general quickness of the genre lends itself really well to creating a stimulating but ultimately stress-free experience.

Why am I telling you this?

There is no denying that Backpack Hero is well designed and generally entertaining, but unlike a lot of other roguelikes it's not relaxing in any way. Not for me, at least.

Runs don't really "flow". You have to keep rotating and moving stuff in your backpack, deciding which items you want to keep, which items you want to throw away, which items you want to upgrade, what to buy or sell at the merchant, etc. You spend way more time managing your build than you do actually using it in fights. Once I finish a run I often feel exhausted rather than motivated to try another.

That being said, the question Steam asks when you're writing a review isn't "Would you recommend this game to yourself?" It's "Would you recommend this game to other players?"

And my answer is yes. If strategic inventory management with a side of turn-based combat sounds like a fun time to you then I definitely recommend giving Backpack Hero a try.

If you're like me, however, and prefer to enjoy your roguelikes with a Josh Strife Hayes video on your second monitor and a cup of tea, coffee, or hot chocolate on your desk, I recommend looking elsewhere.

132398179.review:
I'm going to go wild with the non-recommendation. First off, don't take this as scathing criticism of the game, but I wanted to make sure my concerns were highlighted well enough. 

My closest relevant experience to this game is probably Slay the Spire so that's what I'll use for my constructive criticism.

The game drew me in and hooked me due to the unique inventory management system being the way the game works. It's like making a game out of RE:4 inventory management screen. I actually do really like the game, and it is a ton of fun to play a run. The characters you can play as are actually quite refreshingly unique in their mechanics. It's not Slay the Spire in that characters just get their own unique cards, but each character here gets their own _mechanics_. It's sweet to have a character focused on pets and managing their inventories too. It's cool that a robot is focused on strategic aiming of a charge pulse through your backpack as the only way to activate your items. However there are some stark difficulties I have that I want to share here.

The largest problem so far is just an overall lack of clarity in pretty much everything. Some of that comes in the limited sprite assets not being high enough resolution and/or poor UI placement, and some comes from no tutorials that tell you what a character's gimmick is. For example - if I summon a pet, which spot does the pet go in? If I rearrange the player/pet order, who uses the energy? How do I revive a dead pet that is no longer there when I leave the room? Why do I have to open each pet's inventory manually every turn to use their items? Why do some items allow effects to be rotated too but not others? A crystal gem can give a bonus to the weapon above it - I can rotate it left to make the effect go left instead, but rotating boots doesn't adjust which direction it checks for spaces to increase the armor value it provides? "Above" changes to "left" in the text of the gem when rotated, but the boots do not.

The robot with the pulse system uses the normal energy you'd have per turn as it hits the items it pulses through - reducing the remaining value of the pulse by whatever the hit item costs on activation. There's a splitter item that divides the pulse into two even values in different directions when it hits it, but what happens when an odd number is split? All activation costs are in integer values, but how does a pulse utilize 1.5 energy? Not to mention later as you build up a lot more you'll be throwing pulses through splitters, redirectors, batteries, amplifiers, etc. The amount of pure chaos in the pulses is literally impossible to use for calculation. Am I going to kill this guy and not need to shield? WHO KNOWS?! I literally cannot calculate the values of the pulses ahead of time or even in real time to gauge my strategy. 

Next comes balance. For the most part this is actually pretty good, but still needs severe tweaking. There are simply too many items thrown at you, honestly. A chest and post-battle loot can give you upwards of 5-6 items at a time. You can usually take 3 at a time too. Sometimes I'll pick up 4 consumables that deal X damage to enemies. Well the next battle is literally 1 turn long since I just spam them with 0 energy cost. Then the next battle could be 5 enemies at a time in the first dungeon. How am I supposed to deal with that with a wooden sword? I've found three categories of items, in general, as I play through: 
1. 10+ variations of a sword with damages that are extremely similar to the basic sword. Wooden sword does 7dmg for 3 vertical slots and 1 energy. A hooked sword does 10 for 3 hooked slots and 0 energy, but increasing by +1 every use. So every battle I get a maximum of 2 uses of said sword before it's objectively better to use the starting weapon. After that it's 3 wasted slots. Shivs do 2 dmg, take one slot, are free, but can only be used once per turn. Enemies have like 40+ hp in most cases and are almost never alone. It's mostly just a waste of a slot (better for pets though). 
2. A godlike legendary sword/bow that trivializes an entire hour of the game (Jagged Sword). A keg is OP. For 2 gold you can spawn a healing mug. It heals 10hp for 0 energy AND turns into a 0 cost weapon after. AND the keg takes no energy to use AND can be used unlimited times per turn.
3. Items that take too much luck/investment to even get working - i.e. magic. It utilizes a separate resource system but is limited to the size of your mana crystals. You can expect to get 1-2 uses of a _single_ magic item per fight unless you're ungodly lucky with item drops. Why doesn't a character utilize magic as their main weapon type and actually provide good starting gear/progression for it? Any mage character will still be slapping people with a sword the entire game anyways.

You can survive most of the time by piecing together builds as you go, but some of the items are just flat-out game ruining if you can find one. And they are not really that rare to be honest. Speaking of game-ruining. You can be doing quite well or holding on well enough for a long time only to be ended completely by a single encounter. One of my godly runs ended because an encounter had 3 enemies - one with over 700hp. My super buffed sword did 70dmg per hit for 1 energy, but they hit for nearly 30-40 damage. I only have 45hp. Even with solid block and a decent few pieces of armor you're looking at 20block passively? Another run I decided to kick a plant in the very first room I walked into - it starts an encounter. Well it was 3 enemies that spam heals for ~20 each on ALL enemies at once. Wooden sword? Literally impossible to win the first room. 

I really enjoy build-as-you-go games because it makes me think creatively, but what kind of build am I doing when most of my items are one-time consumables? I can't do a shuriken build because getting spammed with them in 2 battles doesn't guarantee I'll ever see one again. In Slay the Spire you will focus on one aspect of a character's strengths in a run. In Backpack Hero you will focus on specific items and try to tailor them to your character's unique playstyle. In the end no matter who you play as, your run is always dictated by hoping for the strongest legendary items and their buff/synergies. Every character will get mileage out of that Jagged Sword I mentioned. 

Why can I get an hour into a run and the gold/heart/exp drop rooms still only give 5 of their resource? I need 150xp for a level...

So far as I can tell there's no real reward system for playing either. No new card packs, character levels, or other unlocks. Slay the Spire doesn't have as much breadth of content as what BH is trying for, but it is _solidly_ balanced, consistent, and predictable. 

I want to be clear here. The only reason I am being this harsh is because I saw that the plan for EA was 7 months and we are ~6 months in from original release. I have not done much research or followed any roadmaps/updates, so this is all judgment based on my experience going in blind. There's a ton of potential here, but at the moment it just isn't there for me. I have no doubts this can be great, but I do have doubts that it will be soon.
132398179.developer_response: Thanks for writing such a detailed review! You've brought up some really important points for us to work on. A lot of players have been mentioning a lack of clarity and helpful tutorials lately, so it's definitely something we're looking to improve. We're also working on finding the right balance for the game. We hope you'll give Backpack Hero another shot and see the changes we're making! :)

Fun, but not worth full price. Ultimately, it feels like a lot of the gameplay is set up so that you either kill all enemies on turn 1 (except bosses), or you lose. Enemies are very same-y feeling, you don't really care what they do other than if they have thorns.

For a rogue-like, it has very little replayability. It feels like win/lose is decided based on getting some broken scaling combo rather than incrementally due to making choices.

The UI is a bit clunky. There are a number of places where it feels like there are extra steps for no reason. Clicked on the stairs to go to the next level? Yep, you have to click again. Finished picking your item from rewards? Now you have to click on the map to proceed, rather than it just popping up.

131458609.review:
Edit:  I flipped the review to recommend.  The game has a great, original concept, the developers have obviously put a lot of time and effort into the game, and the game is fun and enjoyable, so it feels wrong to leave a negative review, especially when the dev can potentially lose sales due to negative reviews.

Original:  I have had a lot of fun with this game, however I am marking this as negative because there are some issues that hold it back from being a great game, and I want to make sure the developer sees this so it will be a great game and I can update the review and flip it to being positive.

I'll start with my biggest issue: there's no sense of accomplishment.  After playing and beating it, it's pretty deflating to see a wedge of cheese with throwaway text and a Start Over button, and that's after a wall of stats pop up after you beat a boss that you're not even aware is the final boss.  Now, obviously the ideal would be something like The Binding of Issac where there are multiple possible endings with actual cutscenes, but if that is beyond the scope of the game, at least have some celebratory artwork, credits, and music.
I realize that in the store meta-progression (in an overworld, no less) is planned for the final release, so hopefully that will be addressed there, but another element of the lack of accomplishment is the complete lack of Steam Achievements.  I've done some pretty cool stuff in the game, like kill the final boss in one turn, kill 5 enemies with a single move, beat the harder modes, beat the game without taking damage, etc., but it feels kind of hollow without the little thrill of getting an achievement.

Another aspect that feels pretty hollow is the endless mode.  I had a pretty overpowered build, and went into the endless mode after beating the game, but the ramping of the enemies is terrible, it didn't take long before the enemies had over 8K HP and became a brick wall.

Now obviously this being Early Access there are some glitches and oversights (like Rage not powering up Scratch, for example, the ninja helmets being unusable if you've reorganized them into a pouch after using them, or more serious issues like not being able to click on anything and having to exit the game) but I expect these to get worked out, that's what Early Access is there for anyways, but some things are missing that were in the demo, and that's puzzling.  For example, in the demo when you grab one of your items in the shop, it will immediately tell you how much the shopkeeper will buy them for.  For some reason that's missing in the full game, and from trial and error you'll discover that the prices are based on the rarity of the item, so not a huge issue for experienced players, but an unnecessary hurdle for new players.

131392160.review:
It's really fun and interesting concept. Unfortunately the architecture of the game is built in a way, that at some point in the game, you basically lock down your backpack build and you go with it until you finish the game or die trying. At this point the game becomes pointless and you basically just click away until the end. There is no real variation with the enemies, that would require you to figure out new tactics to survive. 

I see this troublesome for the developers, because your backpack build is difficult to change fast, so is is almost impossible to even vary the enemies much, as players wouldn't have anything to counter the changes. IMO this all boils down to the  core concept of backpack organizing, which is nice on paper, but is really restrictive when you try to build a good game around it. Good comparison of this would be Slay the spire, where you have game changing relics, and literally multiple different ways to kill the enemies and the enemies have also many different ways to kill you. I really hope that the developers can find a way the fix this issue, as in its current form, the game get repetitive very fast.

129724721.review:
Backpack hero is a cute little game with a good core idea, but mediocre execution. If you approach the game like you would solitaire, minesweeper, or something like that, you will find a great way to pass 30-60mins of your time. If you are looking for a slay the spire -style game that will have you spend 200 hours, steer clear. 

The core problem of Backpack Hero is the lack of variety in builds: for a given character, there are 2-3 OP builds one of which you can basically make happen every time. This is especially bad for the robot, with whom I've run the same exact setup with different weapons every time, winning easily, but is also a big problem for all characters. There are some fun, weird builds that you can make work, but you need to go out of your way, and it might fail. If, instead, you find a bow, gg, you win automatically. 

The runs individually are also slightly too long, partly because the combats just take quite long. Especially later on in a run, you play the game on autopilot, and it just becomes a game of clicking until you win. 

I hope they will introduce more content in the future, and find ways to incorporate challenges into the game better. As it stands, they are an extra mode selection, and there's no reward, no progression, no real anything. Just extra challenges, attached to the game. For some gamers those work, for me, they are not motivating to play. 

Despite the copmlaints, I've played the game a lot, and enjoy it. Just make sure you play it in bite-sized chunks, and you will find a charming little game, just perfect for those 30min breaks you have somewhere in your day.

129583601.review:
The Time Traveller (for so it will be convenient to speak of him) was expounding a recondite matter to us. His pale grey eyes shone and twinkled, and his usually pale face was flushed and animated. The fire burnt brightly, and the soft radiance of the incandescent lights in the lilies of silver caught the bubbles that flashed and passed in our glasses. Our chairs, being his patents, embraced and caressed us rather than submitted to be sat upon, and there was that luxurious after-dinner atmosphere, when thought runs gracefully free of the trammels of precision. And he put it to us in this way—marking the points with a lean forefinger—as we sat and lazily admired his earnestness over this new paradox (as we thought it) and his fecundity.

“You must follow me carefully. I shall have to controvert one or two ideas that are almost universally accepted. The geometry, for instance, they taught you at school is founded on a misconception.”

“Is not that rather a large thing to expect us to begin upon?” said Filby, an argumentative person with red hair.

“I do not mean to ask you to accept anything without reasonable ground for it. You will soon admit as much as I need from you. You know of course that a mathematical line, a line of thickness nil, has no real existence. They taught you that? Neither has a mathematical plane. These things are mere abstractions.”

“That is all right,” said the Psychologist.

“Nor, having only length, breadth, and thickness, can a cube have a real existence.”

“There I object,” said Filby. “Of course a solid body may exist. All real things—”

“So most people think. But wait a moment. Can an instantaneous cube exist?”

“Don’t follow you,” said Filby.

“Can a cube that does not last for any time at all, have a real existence?”

Filby became pensive. “Clearly,” the Time Traveller proceeded, “any real body must have extension in four directions: it must have Length, Breadth, Thickness, and—Duration. But through a natural infirmity of the flesh, which I will explain to you in a moment, we incline to overlook this fact. There are really four dimensions, three which we call the three planes of Space, and a fourth, Time. There is, however, a tendency to draw an unreal distinction between the former three dimensions and the latter, because it happens that our consciousness moves intermittently in one direction along the latter from the beginning to the end of our lives.”

“That,” said a very young man, making spasmodic efforts to relight his cigar over the lamp; “that . . . very clear indeed.”

“Now, it is very remarkable that this is so extensively overlooked,” continued the Time Traveller, with a slight accession of cheerfulness. “Really this is what is meant by the Fourth Dimension, though some people who talk about the Fourth Dimension do not know they mean it. It is only another way of looking at Time. There is no difference between Time and any of the three dimensions of Space except that our consciousness moves along it. But some foolish people have got hold of the wrong side of that idea. You have all heard what they have to say about this Fourth Dimension?”

“I have not,” said the Provincial Mayor.

“It is simply this. That Space, as our mathematicians have it, is spoken of as having three dimensions, which one may call Length, Breadth, and Thickness, and is always definable by reference to three planes, each at right angles to the others. But some philosophical people have been asking why three dimensions particularly—why not another direction at right angles to the other three?—and have even tried to construct a Four-Dimensional geometry. Professor Simon Newcomb was expounding this to the New York Mathematical Society only a month or so ago. You know how on a flat surface, which has only two dimensions, we can represent a figure of a three-dimensional solid, and similarly they think that by models of three dimensions they could represent one of four—if they could master the perspective of the thing. See?”

“I think so,” murmured the Provincial Mayor; and, knitting his brows, he lapsed into an introspective state, his lips moving as one who repeats mystic words. “Yes, I think I see it now,” he said after some time, brightening in a quite transitory manner.

“Well, I do not mind telling you I have been at work upon this geometry of Four Dimensions for some time. Some of my results are curious. For instance, here is a portrait of a man at eight years old, another at fifteen, another at seventeen, another at twenty-three, and so on. All these are evidently sections, as it were, Three-Dimensional representations of his Four-Dimensioned being, which is a fixed and unalterable thing.

“Scientific people,” proceeded the Time Traveller, after the pause required for the proper assimilation of this, “know very well that Time is only a kind of Space. Here is a popular scientific diagram, a weather record. This line I trace with my finger shows the movement of the barometer. Yesterday it was so high, yesterday night it fell, then this morning it rose again, and so gently upward to here. Surely the mercury did not trace this line in any of the dimensions of Space generally recognised? But certainly it traced such a line, and that line, therefore, we must conclude, was along the Time-Dimension.”

“But,” said the Medical Man, staring hard at a coal in the fire, “if Time is really only a fourth dimension of Space, why is it, and why has it always been, regarded as something different? And why cannot we move in Time as we move about in the other dimensions of Space?”

The Time Traveller smiled. “Are you so sure we can move freely in Space? Right and left we can go, backward and forward freely enough, and men always have done so. I admit we move freely in two dimensions. But how about up and down? Gravitation limits us there.”

“Not exactly,” said the Medical Man. “There are balloons.”

“But before the balloons, save for spasmodic jumping and the inequalities of the surface, man had no freedom of vertical movement.”

“Still they could move a little up and down,” said the Medical Man.

“Easier, far easier down than up.”

“And you cannot move at all in Time, you cannot get away from the present moment.”

“My dear sir, that is just where you are wrong. That is just where the whole world has gone wrong. We are always getting away from the present moment. Our mental existences, which are immaterial and have no dimensions, are passing along the Time-Dimension with a uniform velocity from the cradle to the grave. Just as we should travel down if we began our existence fifty miles above the earth’s surface.”

“But the great difficulty is this,” interrupted the Psychologist. ’You can move about in all directions of Space, but you cannot move about in Time.”

“That is the germ of my great discovery. But you are wrong to say that we cannot move about in Time. For instance, if I am recalling an incident very vividly I go back to the instant of its occurrence: I become absent-minded, as you say. I jump back for a moment. Of course we have no means of staying back for any length of Time, any more than a savage or an animal has of staying six feet above the ground. But a civilised man is better off than the savage in this respect. He can go up against gravitation in a balloon, and why should he not hope that ultimately he may be able to stop or accelerate his drift along the Time-Dimension, or even turn about and travel the other way?”

“Oh, this,” began Filby, “is all—”

“Why not?” said the Time Traveller.

“It’s against reason,” said Filby.

“What reason?” said the Time Traveller.

“You can show black is white by argument,” said Filby, “but you will never convince me.”

“Possibly not,” said the Time Traveller. “But now you begin to see the object of my investigations into the geometry of Four Dimensions. Long ago I had a vague inkling of a machine—”

“To travel through Time!” exclaimed the Very Young Man.

“That shall travel indifferently in any direction

129550858.review: Very cute, slay the spire style combat with interesting and unique mechanic involving choosing and organizing your loot. Highly recommend. The demo is free, and lets you play through an entire standard run.

129490741.review:
Truly a wonderful game with a clever premise! It's inventory management: the game! Like tetris? Like sorting and organizing? Like optimizing everything so it fits *just* right? Ever wanted to just chuck stuff from your backpack at dungeon enemies? This is the game for you!

The devs have built a wicked cool combat mechanic based around your character's trusty bag and an ever-growing suite of items you find throughout an ever-shifting dungeon. They've struck a perfect balance of difficulty and fun, and aren't afraid to let you run away with a totally ridiculous backpack build if you're smart enough to arrange one. The amount of flexibility and customization baked into the game means we get nearly endless options for play style. Each character adds unique mechanics and strategies. Not to mention adorable art and personality! The soundtrack is full of bops, too.

Even in early access, the game feels smooth, satisfying, and complete. AND STILL! This is clearly a labor of love because the devs release incredibly frequent (!!! Seriously! Devs! Y'all are amazing!) updates and even seasonal content (Halloween and Winter Holidays so far). I'm excited to see what gets added to the lore and world building behind this ridiculously fun bag-based adventure.

 I've even found that playing on the testing branch doesn't break the game in any meaningful way (sure, you can tell it's a little scruffier, but not in a way that impacts fun).

Please give this little game a shot! I've had hours of fun with it already, and if you're still not convinced, the dev team offers a very-very-very-early version (a mere glimmer of what it is now!) of the game for free on itch.io Go try it! Find yourself sitting there wondering where the last 3 hours went and why you haven't added this absolute gem to your game library yet!

A fantastic roguelite with some very refreshing mechanics. It couples inventory management with the usual dungeon traversal. You have limited space in your inventory (which does grow quite a bit as you level) so you'll have to prioritise what items to take. There are multiple weapons and as of writing this, five characters.

The goal of the game is to beat three levels (3x3 floors). There are also challenges for those seeking them and they can get quite difficult, especially the final hard modes. I am a fan of our robot overlord (CR-8 supremacy) and you will find that all characters change up the way you approach the dungeon because the mechanics differ with each. One summons weapons and items from a pool much like card games, one summons pets, you get the drift. 

As for weapons there are multiple kinds. You have cleavers, bows, shivs, wands, shurikens, swords, a floating sword that scales off of the number of bricks you have around it, a wand that summons shivs, a staff that turns into a sword, etc. Once again you get the drift.

Thus the runs end up having a lot of variety and will keep you hooked for hours on end. So definitely give this a shot.

Unfortunately, once your build is completed, every turn is essentially repeating the same action over and over, because it's inefficient do do anything other than the 3-4 actions which are optimised according to your build. In result, the mid and late game turns into a grind of pointing and clicking the same moves every turn.

For feedback, I would love the addition of a ''repeat last turn'' function, so instead of pointing and clicking 6 times to do my battle turn, I can just click once. I wish I could play this game more to enjoy the build variety but in its current state, it is much too grindy once your build is completed because you're just repeating the exact same point-and-click pattern for each battle every, single, time.

This game is wonderful, and I really enjoy it so far. I'll list some pros and cons of the game, as well as any misc information I have noticed so far. 
Pros:
Music is absolutely amazing at parts
The inventory management part is fun, but it doesn't take up the whole game. If it seems boring to arrange an inventory, just know, it isn't just that and has much more to it.
Many different builds to try, with different characters changing the gameplay formula drastically. 
Items are rather unique, and add depth to gameplay instead of just damage ups.
Many special ? and ! rooms can shake up a run
SAVING DURING A RUN, this is a big one, and it makes a single misclick less unforgiving.

Cons:
Certain builds can b hard to learn. (At least for me, the mana items took so long to get used to how they work)
Certain builds NEED a specific few items to work, which can be limiting.
As it is in early access, still has some balancing to go.
Some weapons are just better than others. (straight upgrades, which means if you get unlucky you don't get these straight upgrades)
Some builds just seem bad, or hard to make work. (For me, I find structures like brick to be less good than just armor.)

Overall, I highly recommend this game. I personally think people should buy it on a sale, if possible, but once it is done I think It will be well worth the price!

127801823.review:
This is actually one of the better roguelites I’ve played in some time. It’s got a simple yet solid set of game mechanics that is just so much fun to play even with the (plenty) of flaws the current game has. In addition the game doesn’t (currently) lock its content behind a frustrating timesink wall that requires you to grind out hours in order to progress. ‘Progression’ systems have ruined otherwise enjoyable games for me, so I’m really happy to see that isn’t the case here. The short version of this review is that if you like roguelites with more a space management/micromanagement vibe, Backpack Hero will definitely scratch that itch.

The base gameplay of Backpack Hero involves reducing the HP of a parade of enemies to 0 as you traverse a dungeon to fight the boss. There’s not much of a plot, though with all the items and enemies you could probably hack together some Dark Souls like lore nonsense if you really felt compelled. The primary loop of the game involves killing (or sometimes befriending) enemies, getting loot, then using that loot to defeat new enemies. None of this probably sounds impressive, and indeed, there isn’t really anything Backpack Hero does that’s new. What makes it so enjoyable is just how hard it leans into that rote RPG experience.

All your items take up space, and the ‘game’ isn’t so much what you do in battles, but how you prepare for them. Certain items require space in your titular backpack in order to function. Some require proximity to other items, some need to be spaced far away from other items. Some items need literal space to move around between turns. When you’re choosing what to add to your inventory, you are constantly playing a game of what you need right now vs what will be useful later. In a weird twist in a game about a backpack, hoarding can be to your detriment, and the game actively pushes you to use consumables rather than stockpiling them. There isn’t one right way to play and every floor can be a game of figuring out what your priorities need to be and how to adapt to what gets thrown at you. This foundation is incredibly enjoyable, and kept me coming back to clear out the more challenging modes.

With that said, there’s a lot to turn your nose up at as well. Enemies are basically just damage dealers, and there isn’t much creativity on that front. Enemy types can look really similar, which doesn’t really matter because they rarely do anything different from one another anyway, but combined with the somewhat bland art style it’s easy to look at the game and not be terribly impressed by what you’re looking at. The UI is buggy, and particularly on the puzzle game modes,  downright incomprehensible. The music isn’t that good, and the sound design could use more work to be more satisfying. The base gameplay is more of a tutorial level difficulty and you will probably clear your first game by complete accident. The harder difficulties and challenge modes are truly where the game shines, as each game becomes its own unique puzzle to solve, but if you just play the bog standard mode you’ll probably get bored very quickly. I would highly recommend the higher difficulties, at least up to Hard Mode 3, which is as far as I've gotten.

There are at the time of this review 5 wildly different characters to play as in addition, which is impressive even if I don’t think they all hit the mark. The mouse character and robot are standouts to me, with the robot in particular being a clever twist on autobattlers that honestly feels compelling enough that it could be its own game. Unfortunately I found the frog and hedgehog (?) characters very tedious to play, owing in part to clunky UI. 

Looking forward to see what the team does when the game is out of early access!

127787795.review:
A game about inventory management sounded interesting, and I don't regret the purchase. However, it wasn't exactly as I imagined.
There are, truthfully, plenty of choices in the way you can progress, from direct damage to buffing up your defenses, even charming enemies to strike in your stead. There are different classes of weapons, some which use stamina, magical energy or both, enabling some choices in how you play.
But the biggest letdown in my playthroughs was that, excluding the postioning of weapons and accessories for their innate effects, there are no interactions between your items beyond that. 
I can place a gem to imbue my weapon with poison damage, however I can't place a poisonous herb in front of an arrow to make a poisonous arrow. There is a type of arrow which uses mana gems to deliver more damage: it's an arrow with a lightning bolt tip. There is also a gem with the same design. Again, placing an actual arrow with that same gem in its path doesn't have any interaction beyond the abilities of each single component.

To say it again, I don't regret my purchase. It is a fun roguelike, with inventory management as its main feature, as was promised. However, it could be more than just management of its singular items, it could be management of their intrinsic effects and interactions of their sinergies.

Fantastic game. If you like turn based roguelikes like Slay the Spire or Monster Train, give this one a whirl. It's not the same mechanics, but it scratches the same itch and gets you coming back for more.
It's still early in EA but even with what's available right now, it's a great time!
Also very cute.

EA, so things may change, but right now:
+ Excellent gameplay/mechanics
+ Fair bit of strategic depth
+ Charming character design
+ Really good replayability

- The world/dungeon is super uninteresting. No story, only a handful of words setup. Simple dungeon areas with almost no interesting background art to distinguish them, and no world outside the dungeons.
It doesn't matter too much, since the strategy is the real draw here, but it is kind of a downer.
- Endless mode: As soon as the final boss is killed the first time, xp progress drops off a cliff and difficulty ramps extremely fast. Definitely needs some balancing.
- Thin on quality of life UI info. That will come later I'm sure.

Don't be disuaded by the negatives though, compared to the great gameplay they are almost afterthoughts.

127263108.review:
This game is a very refreshing take on the rogue-like/lite formula. 

The fun (and skill-expression) in rogue-likes/lites can be roughly separated into two parts: preparing for conflict and the conflict itself. All rogue-likes/lites place different amounts of importance on each aspect. The extreme end of conflict-focused rogue-likes/lites would be Heat Signature, where there is hardly any preparation and the fun is in improvising based on what you're given. Somewhere in the middle would be deckbuilding rogue-likes/lites like Slay the Spire or Inscryption (the first act) where the cards you choose to put into your deck can change your odds greatly but you still need to make good decisions during the battles. That is usually as far as games go towards conflict preparation-focused gameplay: somewhere in the middle where both aspects of gameplay are equally important. This is the first rogue-like/lite that I've played that crosses the line to the other side where the preparation for the battles is more important than how you play the battle itself (depending on your build and character). There is even a character (CR-8) where battles are almost entirely autonomous. This game also challenges some preconceived notions the gaming community has about what makes fun gameplay. Inventory management has always been seen as a necessary evil that no player enjoys having to deal with but is necessary because it accentuates other aspects of the gameplay such as scarcity of resources and the tension that results from it. However, this game shows that even aspects of games that players begrudgingly go along with (inventory management) can be made to be deeply nuanced and satisfying if done correctly. This game makes me wonder what other parts of gameplay that players frequently moan about can be made to become beloved as well. May I even daringly suggest escort missions?

Regardless of how you feel about inventory management in video games, this game is worth at least a try simply due to how it can change how you think about gameplay mechanics. It is especially worth if you are excited about innovations in how games find the fun.

"Simple" to pick up, difficult to master. The idea is you have a backpack that grows bigger as you explore, and it's up to you to tetris your way to victory, using what you find to defeat the multitude of enemies keeping you from your cheesy reward (if you are playing as Purse).

I am nowhere near an expert, and with the additions to the game with the updates, it gets all the more fun trying to manage the new things. I love it, and sometimes "Simple" is the best way to go. The graphics aren't going to be cutting edge, because they don't have to be, the pixelated designs are great and have their own charm and difficulty to make compared to 3D models and meshes and all that. 

Sound design also follows the pixelated design, using 'less is more' for easy to recognize sounds once you hear them a few times. The theme music is catchy and gets your attention and both the dungeon loop and combat loop are engaging, feeling thematic to what you are doing.

Lots of game modes, different characters that all have different play styles.

Every game is different which makes the game very repayable.

The different types of equipment and the combo's you can create with them also allow for very fun builds and set-ups. 

Besides some minor bugs (the ones I've encountered have all been fixable by saving and reloading the run,and very few in total), the game runs smooth, with pathing choices that do make a difference, although small ones. (for example, the magma path you encounter fire, and the glacial path, you guessed it, ice modifier).

There are not many cons of buying this game. My only concern/improvement would be that further down the run (endless loops) difficulty is scaled by more hp and higher attack. I would like to see difficulty be slightly more than just one-shot them or be one-shot, or make sure you have enough dodge buffs.

Also receiving quite frequent updates with gameplay changes, seasonal updates (for example the halloween update that added themed candy consumables ect. and the upcomming winter update) 

Overall im having a lot of fun, 10/10

I played the demo of this game and had a ton of fun. This is brought a lot of extra content that was not in the demo and it is appreciated for sure. I love the fact that I can change my character to look different, an addition that was not something I even considered being added. The new items since the demo are also very fun to try and learn. Over all this is a terrific game and I think anyone who likes a roguelike will find hours of enjoyment in this tactical and thoughtful approach to combat.

My one issue I found as I played, was the fact that I couldn't unlock the full potential of my backpack. I beat the boss at the end and continued on into the endless mode and still had so many slots to fill. 124626887.review:
I'll start with the caveat that I think this game is at least a really interesting idea and could conceivably have some potential if reworked. 

While I initially had fun in my first few hours of the game, once you get past the basics, you start to realize some core problemb with the game: 

- Because you always have access to all your tools in a non-random way, once you've found your build for the run, you're pretty much just doing the same thing every turn. It's not even hard to put together some basic builds that generate so much value either by bursting enemies down or by providing enough free block every turn that you don't need to dedicate any energy to it. 

- Another problem related to the first point is that enemies don't really provide varied challenges. You can mostly just defeat them all in the same way by becoming generically stronger. You don't need to evolve your strategy and adapt as you go on, you just need to keep adding power. The game even has different zones you can sometimes choose between but for the life of me I couldn't tell you what was different about them other than the background art. 

- Because you're so limited on space and many builds take up a lot of space to combo and be effective, it's really hard to pivot your build based on finding new cool items. In a deckbuilder like slay the spire, the cost of adding a currently dead card to your deck is just that you will occasionally draw it in a hand of 5+ cards instead of something else. In this game, you might have to give up a critical part of your current build that will make you much weaker in fights on a speculative item that may not pay off. Because of this, you very quickly get to a point where you're leaving behind or maybe selling pretty much all high rarity items that don't fit your build. 

I'd definitely check it out again after a few updates or maybe 1.0, but for now it doesn't really feel like the game has the staying power to be a main roguelike.

124488986.review: As of now the game has a lot of bugs with item interactions. Its hard to know what an item means at times, and the tooltips are lack luster. While I have kind of enjoyed the game, it just isn't ready. They say the game will release in April, but I don't see how they can pull that off with so many bad item interactions and a fairly limited item pool. It seems a lot, but depending on the way you build and your tactics, you find that there are not many items that will benefit you. I'd also say they added way too many consumable items. A consumable heavy build is pretty fun I admit. I think there is something at the heart of the game that fundementally isn't working. I think it is to due with the fact that better items are more rare, but there is no item scaling. That is, to some extent fine for the way they have it now. But as it stands there are only 9 floors, 3 bosses and you beat the game....Once you do and go into unlimited mode, the enemy scaling quickly outpaces the items which don't get any better until it becomes numerically impossible which isn't a satisfying way to lose and so I don't really do it. Nothing new pops up. I don't know. I'd say wait for a huge sale. Unless in the next 6 months things massively change, I wouldn't suggest the game. I think I've done everything I could have wanted to explore in a couple dozens playthroughs. I'm not a fan of the variety through different characters thing they have going. But thats maybe personal. Seems dangerous to have done that path since it means you now have to balance everything for every character, and if something is too OP for even a single character, it has to become useless for all the others. Kind of a shame. Oh well. Get the game if it goes on sale for $10 or less. I think it is really fun, but for a rogue-like it has shockingly poor replay value in my eyes, considering you don't really get much out of new runs. Its not like I'm trying to improve my reaction times. I simply click things in turn based combat. Not much room to improve there, and I like the turn based thing. I need more chill games, but I just think the game's foundation was faulty from the start. I want a run to last a long time, not after 9 floors. Feels bad to just have it all end so abrupty.

124407320.review:
[h1]Foreword[/h1]
Everything I write here is based on my subjective experience. Your experience may vary and/or be different, be aware of that. No two humans are the same but we could have similarities. Here I write about things I dislike and like about the game. The conclusion will give an overal description.



[h1]What do I dislike?[/h1]
[list]
[*]Balancing (1)
[*]Sound
[*]UI / Menus (2)
[/list]


[h1]What do I like?[/h1]
[list]
[*]Graphics
[*]Animation
[*]Overall character and enemy design
[*]Game idea (3)
[/list]



[h1](1) Balancing[/h1]
The game's balancing is so extremely off that you will experience the "what did I do wrong?"-feeling quite a lot. Not because you did something wrong but because the enemy scale at combat turn 1, fight 1, stage 1. If you are not on your toes the whole time you will face game over extremely fast.

This isn't as prominent within the standard game mode but definitively within some of the harder challenges. Don't get me wrong here: Challenges should be, well, a challenge. But "sheer extreme luck" should not be the only (read exactly!) way to get through a challenge.

My personal approach is always: Luck 1/5, Knowledge & Planning 3/5 and last but not least ressource management 1/5.

Overall the dev(s) are, in my opinion, overburdened with the balancing of the game since they probably not using scalable and modular functions (If you don't know what this is. It's basically a "Lego set" for creating in-game content automatically in which you just have to tweak a single number in most cases)

In game modes in which you are limited to your 3x3 space you can still get items through events that are larger than the space available. But this is rarely happening and thus, for me, just a minor inconvinience - still an inconvinience.



[h1](2) UI / Menus[/h1]
I am not happy with the menus and/or UI design of this game. It get's it's job done but it's not "dumdum proofed" (Which is just a saying.). Especially when picking up loot. You have a button that says "Done picking up loot" which has no right to be existing in any way. You can move on, skip and pick up loot without that button.

Next part is when you want to restart a run. Restart needs you to be in an empty room. This is also, in my opinion, a very bad design choice since when someone want to do a restart, they should do a restart.

Menus don't close automatically if you want to do something else. For me it's a major inconvinience to have to click up to three times to get away from an event (character) that I just want to see what they offer.



[h1](3) Game idea[/h1]
This is where the magnifiency starts for real. Every single character you play has a completely different way to play and/or puzzle the game! You can have the classic character (as in the demo!) which has the biggest inventory space at the end. Another one has a deck-building mechanic within the backpack-building mechanic.

The third character has you to puzzle through your backpack to create a "circuit" of attacks and defenses. Last but definitively not least the currently last character as of this writing: The musician.

The musician uses the 'charm' debuff to 'convince' enemies to be on his side. With the power of music and friendship :) Absolutely fun! And an extreme variety especially with the challenges for each and everyone of those characters. A fifth character is in the work and for me it looks like they have a pet. I am looking forward to this.

Everything else is also very exciting: You have a lot of different combinations of items, weapons, armor and so much more that you will be playing for a while until you have seen everything. Even if you have seen everything you have enough variety to make every playthourgh exciting, no matter the build you go for.

The main mechanic and thus the gameplay loop is executed extremely good yet the balancing throws you off at times. Even if that may sound like a gamebreaking moment you will probably come back for more. Until the balancing is fixed you can skip the extreme challenges and do all the others and there are. A. Lot!





[h1]Overall conclusion[/h1]
If you like Monster Train, Slay the Spire and so many other deck building games, this will be up your alley. I promise you that. Although this game doesn't invent the genre anew it certainly has some serious good mechanics to keep you entertained and coming back.

If you're new to the whole genre of deck-building (or here: backpack tetris ^^) and rogue lite genre, this here makes an excellent entry point since it's easy to understand and easy to master relatively quickly.

I would give this game an absolutely yes on to buy it with or without a sale. This has proofen, for me, to be worth every single cent I've paid.

If the dev(s) can keep it up, the game will be easily a nominee for some serious prices.



Stay crunchy.

124246843.review:
This game presents a very interesting concept and a unique game style that is quite enjoyable to play through. It also has a fairly simple game play loop and a lot of replay-ability. At least in theory. 

The main problem the game ends up having is the sheer number of items, weapons and equipment available to you to choose from but with a combination of pure RNG, highly limited inventory and how much is needed for some builds to even work leaves you with a game that ends up feeling more frustrating than not much of the time. There are a few combinations of items that seem like they'd be fun to try, but ultimately end up being more of a risk than it's worth due to how many different types of items can be thrown at you. 

Structure combinations, cleavers, and magic are among the many options that seem amazing as a concept but very underwhelming and unreliable in reality. They have incredible potential but require a specific set of items to appear in order to make them worth hanging onto which ends up leaving you with defaulting to the reliable pick up instead of hanging onto them hoping a key items shows up to make it all worth it. 

The end result is a game that ends up feeling very frustrating when your loss is just pure RNG giving you an extremely good bow only to never drop one arrow for the entire rest of the run, or give you four really good arrows but not a single bow to use them with, or floors with many locked doors but not a single key drop for the entire run, or a few cleavers that work extremely well with many other cleavers but never giving you more than those two, or many basic cleavers but none of the higher rarity cleavers required to make them worth having. It's not anything the game itself is specifically doing poorly it just seems to be the nature of how the RNG operates and how heavily it's relied on in the game from map generation to item drops. 

Then there's the curses. They seem fun in concept but with a game that relies so heavily on inventory management and specific placements of items, throwing in curses that can at times be impossible to prepare for, especially when the game's RNG throws at you 3 enemies in a single battle that each rotate hitting you with a different curse that tend to be 1 or two squares in size. The cost of not having room for them is taking a bunch of damage and getting rid of them from your inventory can be just as costly ranging from granting the enemy buffs that can result in a run ender if you get rid of them, but can also end the run if you don't get rid of them quickly at the same time. 

The difficulty in this game also ramps up extremely hard at the last third of the game which kills any run that hasn't already gotten really good synergies to work with. The difficulty spike as well as the large variety of items to chose from, as well as the requirements to get many of the combinations to work properly result in a game you will lose 99% of the time by the last area of the game.

Despite how enjoyable the game has the potential to be, the problems that are presented with how the game currently operates makes it hard to recommend. If you enjoy this style of game there is a lot of enjoyment to be had from it, as long as you can get over the many problems it has. Otherwise I'd recommend holding off until the game gets more development and more fine tuning.

I tried the demo and thought to myself "this game is unique enough that I could burn a couple hours," so I bought it. After playing through the full version, I can easily see massive replayability. There are like 30 different "runs" to unlock, all of which slightly or drastically modify gameplay. Then there are (currently) 4 different characters, each of which plays largely different compared to the others. To top it off, there are a multitude of different "builds" to pursue across each character, depending on RNG and what you look for. Just on the first character, I've been a pickaxe gem miner, a hawkeye archer, a shuriken spammer, a full-block build, and a once-per-turn melee build. There's still at least 10 more builds I want to try, JUST on one character.

All in all, just really phenomenal replayability with a very enjoyable gameplay loop. Not too hard, but not too easy either. A perfect game for roguelike fans.

P.S. I made an infinite loop with the robot. I pressed run, and 100 actions later the enemies were all dead before they got a turn.

123798822.review:
I was quite excited for this game after playing the demo online but so far the Early Access experience has been frustrating due to the lack of balancing and rather brazen encounter design. People tend to have this misconception that roguelites will inherently have broken or unbeatable scenarios, which is not necessarily true, but Backpack Hero falls squarely into that category and has fallen into it every single run I have played thus far.

You simply cannot play a balanced run in it so far. Once you understand how to manage your inventory, builds very quickly become one-note nukes with extreme potency at most encounters, but all it takes is one gimmick you can't deal with to instantly kill you. The screen gets very busy with information some of which is unclear, and due to the main mechanic of managing a fairly tight inventory space, you HAVE to specialize if you want to actually deal the sort of damage the game expects from you.

As a result, Backpack Hero ends up feeling a little bit flaccid once you realize what kind of gameplay loop is in store for you. Get extremely strong, die an unavoidable death at a highly specific encounter, reset, and play again knowing that your run, at any point, will end to basically anything. It makes for a frustrating experience where the fun of managing your inventory and figuring out weird builds gets deflated by how much of a brick wall the game will throw at you. This feels like a roguelite that would benefit from being generally more forgiving with some encounters and from a lot of balance reviews to make sure runs can actually be completed without running into the classic problem of unbeatable, unsolvable encounters.

123776760.review:
Quote from the player named Hunter:
With this opinion, he hits the point also mine.

[i]"It seriously pains me to rate this as a no, because I love the actual gameplay of the game, but the recent/upcoming patch has introduced a change which basically changes the game completely.

With the latest patch, the full dungeon map is no longer revealed when entering a floor.

This feels like a small change to make it more 'roguelite feeling', but it drastically warps the core loop of the game of managing your backpack and minmaxing space in order to get incremental gains over time and eventually come out on top.

Part of the appeal was the 'open information' nature of the game. A backpack is fully open information, and its up to you to decide how to organize it. The map really lent to that appeal, since you could strategically plan your exploration around your items. Things like "Should I spend a key now to regain some room in my bag when I know it could be used later for a shop?", "I should hold on to this legend in case the question mark is a 'rarity trade' event". or "I should sell stuff at this shop now, because I know theres a chest coming up and I need room for that" were strategic decisions that I as a player had to make.

Without that 'open information', I feel like Im just throwing things around in the dark, and don't have an extra layer of game on top of the combat system. Its just 'kill thing, see what I find, pigeonhole myself into a build, because I don't know if I can be flexible on this floor, die, repeat'. It feels like I have less agency and choice now, and the choices I do make are inherently devalued where they weren't before.

It might sound overdramatic to say, but this one small change has genuinely ruined the game for me. It completely removed a layer of strategic gameplay that I found engaging on top of the backpack management, and simultaneously devalues the core gameplay loop of managing a backpack's contents through tough decisions.

I've already seen responses that say their next update is a dungeon redesign which will do things like 'add a shop to each floor for reliability', but I hope with all the similar feedback Ive seen they change it back, or even make it an option to toggle. A ""Dungeon Redesign"" can't add strategic depth like the game originally had before this was added.

As it stands now, I can't recommend it but I truly hope to be able to in the future."[/i]

123674076.review:
(Last updated on Dec 9, 2022 - The new character pochette, who was added recently, plays very well and feels somewhat distinct from the rest of the cast. I definitely recommend people to try it out!)

Tl;dr: I think Backpack Hero is worth trying for fans of the roguelike deckbuilder genre (despite how the game is marketed as an inventory management roguelike), just for the innovations it tried. For people new to the genre though, I think the game needs to have a more polished UI and explain more things that come as natural to fans of the genre, but you should still be in for a good time despite that.

Gameplay:
I would say the base concept of adding spatial management to a roguelike is executed very well in this game. Some items work with how they are positioned or how they move to provide combat bonuses, and powerful items are balanced by their size or restriction they place on inventory management, making full use of the spatial management concept.

Pacing:
The pacing of the game is also very good. Each normal run (beating the area 3 boss) takes around 1 hour to finish, which to me feels like a good length. Combat is quick, and generally no animation is excessively long (except for the robot's energy beams). One thing I dislike about the combat is how enemies can grow stronger with time within each combat, especially when it is not communicated to the players. But this should not affect players most of the times. 

Presentation:
(This part is very much my own opinion) The presentation is decent - the music is very good, especially the combat theme and the area themes. On the other hand, the visuals are just okay and really does not stand out as stylish.

Difficulty:
The run progression / difficulty curve feels okay. You are frequently tasked with solving more and more difficult (and varied) combats, and the boss battles do require some preparation, so the game is very engaging when you need to solve these problems. However (personal opinion from someone that is familiar with the genre), when you know what to optimize and find good items or forge options, the run can feel like it is solved, lowering engagement. I would suggest slightly increasing the difficulty, but again it should depend on the data developers have.

Extras:
Finally, did I mention that there're a bunch of custom modes for you to try? Because there is and they boost replayability by a lot. For an early access title, this game has a surprising amount of content.

Now, some issues I think that can be improved on:
The UI
1) The item cards should be slightly reworked. When an item receives many different effects from different sources, the item card will stretch out and go beyond the screen, becoming basically unreadable. There is an option to open a separate window but it isn't the default - maybe it should be?
2) A lot of things are not explained to players. I know that burn and poison are different in how they damage you, but it is not explained unless you hover over the entity suffering from them. Why is it not explained in the item cards that apply them? Also, I didn't understand what the map square with a "!" is about, until a friend pointed out that it shows the area boss - also not explained.
3) There is no tutorial on carving removal. If you are familiar with the genre you would guess you can do that, and you would be right, but the option is behind 2 layers of menus (While in a carvings shop, you need to go to your carvings menu, and then go to the drop down menu of the carving you want to remove via right click, then there's the option). This is VERY unintuitive. Also the option is not fully translated for some languages.

The characters
I don't believe that there needs to be a balance of power level between characters, but I do believe that they should feel unique from each other. There lies my issue with the characters. Of course I could be wrong (especially if the data on developers' side disagrees with my feelings), so interpret this with caution.
1) Currently, pochette and the robot feel sufficiently distinct from the rest of the cast, but the others feels similar-ish. I think the issue here is that the generalist way of playing (The play that is available regardless of the character you are playing) is more powerful than character-specific way of playing for the other 3 characters. For example, it is relatively easy to get a combo of cleavers (good and highly available for all characters besides the robot) or to power up a single legendary weapon to do the heavy lifting, such that I will not need to pick up carvings, care about separate pockets, or consider charming the enemy.
2) Some characters don't start out different enough. I can almost always go to the generalist play style within a few combats from the starting backpack. Maybe making different drop pools at different stages of the game (especially early game) will help diversify playstyle? (I'm happy to see that pochette managed to be different from the rest of the cast by having friendly unit drops as items, which certainly makes me build the character different from the others.)

123351467.review:
*Early Access Review*
Overall rating: 7/10

Overview:
Sound: 6/10 - easy to listen to but quickly forgotten
Graphics: 7/10 - The artwork is nice but it won't blow you away
Story: -/10 - Story? What is this "Story" you speak of? Is it edible?
Game play: 8/10 - addictive and poised to get better with time

Full review:

Having played this game and completed a few runs, I can confidently say that this game nails the concept of turning the headache of inventory management into an excellent game play loop. Characters have there own unique mechanics; from a ninja star throwing Bird that literally makes its enemies fall in love with its flair, to a mechanical marvel with magnificent monster mangling motivation (and it comes with a character specific auto battle ability)! While there is no story or meta progression as of this review, there are plans to expand this game in a huge way. That said, you are looking at the product as is. and it is good. Jump right into a run, crawl the dungeon, secure relics, potions, weapons, and magic then yeet anything that doesn't fit your build into the stratosphere. If you are into turn based rouglikes then give this one a try. It isn't the greatest game ever made, but for the price you can't go wrong.

TLDR:
Addictive and easy to learn, tough to master inventory management rougelike.
Has enough content already to justify the price tag with more on the way.

123250150.review:
This game scratches my itches around resource management so well. There's a lot of potential for "abusively overpowered builds" if you can stomach some time spent carrying around semi-useless items to find the pieces needed to make them work well for you. I've had builds based around Cleavers, bows, consumable items, Shurikens, hurting myself, etc.

It's a very different feel when the upgrades come through item decisions, and skillful players might even end up throwing away a beloved sword or shield midway through when they realize that devoting to one plan might actually optimize their space best.

Game comes with a fair amount of content, considering the extra gamemodes, additional characters that work in odd ways, as well as other features still coming to the game. I'm a little glad it's a bit "easier" as roguelikes go - there are ways to increase the difficulty to get it to suit you, but playing casually, you probably won't be as stressed as a game like Slay the Spire or Dead Cells. That is, unless you have a hoarder mentality and can't get yourself to throw anything away when you receive a Curse.

123247584.review:
Note that this is an alpha review.

The game is currently overall mediocre:
Mediocre art and music, which should be a selling point for pixel games like this (think the standard set by loophero and vampire survivor). This game does not yet hit that.
Mediocre balancing. Lets just say, you either flatout win a fight or suddenly flatout lose a fight. Mostly because at some point the game scales exponentially while you scale rather linearly. Also, you level 5 times rather quickly and then well suddenly almost never.
Mediocre gameplay. Most item interactions are fun and having passive armour is a real good mechanic, but gathering gear is too random. You're dismissing 9/10 reward screens without a second glance because it's just too different or too weak stuff. You don't hit your intended build 9/10 runs. That feels weird.
Mediocre content. At the third level of the dungeon, bosses of the first level are just recycled as mobs. I mean, that's challenging, but not really refreshing content. The random events are also either blatant slay the spire copy pastes or uninterestingly bland.

As such, seeing as this game is still in alpha and it already scores mediocre, I do really feel it will likely fix some of its issues and hit good and excellent marks.

Switched the rating from recommend to not recommend since the developers decided to take the game out of Early Access. The game is not finished, it is incomplete and full of bugs.

To know whether the game is finally good to purchase, check the Steam forum. If it only has 1 or less bug report thread, then that means it is stable.

Original review:
Very good game for the most part, I recommend it to anyone who likes strategy rpgs, inventory management and Slay The Spire.

Although it is an Early Access game, it is already fairly complete and functions just fine. There are still issues to correct, and the story mode to add according to the roadmap, however, it provides far more content than most other betas and games in Early Access, including several playable characters with each a unique gameplay gimmick. 

Furthermore, it is dangerously addicting. In terms of replay value, this game is great at it. It is full of extra challenge modes to test your skills at the game to the best of your ability.


My only complaint would be for how much the game is causing problems when the developer is putting out updates. Sometimes, a new item will be added that will be overwhelmingly more powerful than every other item in-game and sometimes the opposite is true. Sometimes, a new feature is added that nobody likes.

The oldest occurrence of this issue, regarding balance, was back when magic items were added. Mana was a finite stackable resource much like money is. However, because it was stackable and it had no cap, it was absolutely overpowered. By picking up books and wizard clothings, it was possible to generate an endless supply of mana during fights, which meant anyone could just just get as much mana as needed on a prior fight before beating the enemies and then, given the right circumstances, just spam the wand until they win the next battle. This was changed into the current system which is fine and works well. 
This mechanic stayed in the game in spirit. If you can manage to find the Orksork Axe, you are gonna have a great time. Unfortunately, there is no item that generates money for free (only items that generate money whenever the player kills enemies and the piggy bank that generates money at the end of fights), so it is not nearly as broken, but in the gamemode "Penny Pincher" it gets powerful and in the gamemode "No Experience", it is almost mandatory just to win the game. Though admittedly, it is a legendary item, so that is fine by me.

Regardless, an old running-gag regarding balance were the Cleavers. The Cleavers are weapons that combo off each other. They used to cost 1 energy to use, but now they cost 2. Anyway, who cares! With the shield spirit, their cost is irrelevant. This brings another problem with the way these items are balanced, they are all tested in a vacuum and then released into the wild when, in fact, these items often synergize with other items for the most optimal and broken outcomes. 
I think for this reason, the Shield Spirit needs a nerf of some sort. My proposal would be to remove the -1 damage to weapons, and change it into a +1 energy cost to shields, similarly to the Barbells. 

Anyway, back on topic. There is an item in the game called "Doru", this item is a 1 base damage/2 energy cost weapon that gains +16 damage per turn. Would you believe me if I told you that this item used to have, respectively, a 1 energy cost and then a 3 energy cost? Although, that did happen.
When the item was first introduced it had a 1 energy cost and it was overpowered. Once the developer finally realized it, he increased the cost from 1 to 3, but 3 energy was expensive, therefore, nobody ever used that weapon. Finally, it was improved to cost only 2 energy.
This weapon's history in the game is the perfect example of "I do not know what I am doing", honestly.

A more recent case (as recent as the game being released to the public in Steam Early Access in fact.) regards the cactus item. The cactus received an astronomical buff. It used to be rare and would add +1 spike whenever the player took damage, it is now common and adds +7 spikes whenever the player takes damage. This is plainly absurd, not only this effect can be triggered [b]on purpose[/b] via the Stopwatch and the Tooth Necklace, but even without these two items, by stacking cacti in the player's backpack and then forget to block once to actually take a hit, the player can just watch their foes take their own lives very quickly. 
This item does not ring me as a common item, it rings me as a [b]Legendary[/b] item. It has yet to be fixed as of the writing of this review. This item actually went through the Doru's arc in reverse: it used to suck, but it was made overwhelmingly powerful. 
The developer added another item called the "Crab Cactus" alongside the beefing up of the regular cactus, and let me tell you, comparatively this item is bad. It activates only when the enemy attacks, not when the player takes damage, plus it provides a worse effect: it adds only +2 spikes. Yet, this one is considered legendary by the game's standards.

I mostly spoke about overpowered items, but the Philosopher's Stone exists. It is a Legendary item that adds +1 energy per adjacent consumable which it then destroys. Most consumables are better off consumed than burned off this way, and there are consumables that not only give the player energy, but also provides them with healing like the Frothy Drink. 
Why would I use the Philosopher's Stone in conjunction with the Frothy Drink when it is better to just keep the Frothy Drink and use it directly? By the way, the log costs 1 energy to use, so it is not even a good excuse to use the herbs with the Philosopher's Stone, it just sucks.

And don't get me started with the Shurikens. Just look at the community tab and check for any post concerning these items to see for yourself. Oh my gosh.

And I believe this is tiring for everybody to bring these issues up, it would be better if the items were added and then they were already perfectly balanced as all things should be. 

If items being overpowered and underpowered was the only problem that would be one thing, but recently there have been many people who were upset at the newly added features by the developer. Notably, the forge having a limit and the map being covered and slowly revealing itself as the player progresses through the dungeon. The expression "If it ain't broke, don't fix it" should be taken more seriously here.


In conclusion, my only recommendation for the developer would be to [b]hire a beta tester[/b] before putting the updates live because this would prevent these issues from happening. Technically, anybody who plays the testing branch is a beta tester, but with a massive amount of people, this is difficult to get the proper feedback, and thus, the developer should entrust 1 person and 1 person only to get access to the updates before anyone else, and then get feedback from that person alone. Let's call them the V.I.P beta tester.
