122946434.review:
After reading EVERY SINGLE REVIEW for this game on Steam, I can confirm that the negative reviews are just salty tryhards. This is one of the most addicting and challenging roguelikes in the history of the genre. If you're a fan of inventory management especially, you literally cannot find a better game on Steam. Casual players can just play the game on Standard or Classic Mathew and get enough replayability out of the game to justify the pricepoint. For those who like a challenge, this game is infinitely replayable. And that's with only 4 available characters, with many more coming in the future. The developers have a dedicated road map that they have been sticking to since release. The devs are quick to respond, they listen to feedback, and they really care about the community, sometimes to a fault (balancing to make the game less challenging, as opposed to respecting their original vision and sticking with a more challenging approach). This isn't even something that bothers me really, I'm just not a fan of developers being pressured by players to make their games easier, but there is still plenty of challenge for players like me. And if it gets more people playing the game, I'm not going to complain.

Pros:
- Strong Character/Build Variety
- Endless Replayability
- Great Music
- Timeless Art Style
- Great Community

Cons (These are more warnings to new players than actual marks against the game):
- Some challenge modes are EXTREMELY difficult. Like, dying on the first encounter difficult. It's important to learn and understand the game deeply before tackling some of the later challenges, but they're not all gated so any new player can just click on some of the more difficult runs/characters, get deleted, and then blame the game/devs and post a negative Steam review. So this is more of a warning than an actual knock against the game.

- Lack of Progression. Most roguelikes/roguelites will offer some kind of external progression beyond the core gameplay and since this is early access, at the time of writing this review, there is nothing like this HOWEVER, the devs have an entire update coming within the next few months that will add in these features along with MUCH MORE CONTENT. It bears clarifying that this is one of the most complete feeling Early Access games I've played in years just due to how well designed the core gameplay is and the amount of variety just on launch.

It's going to be hard to find a better game this year, at least for me. The build/item variety, the addicting gameplay, the inventory management, the art style, music, it's all wonderful. This game has a very timeless quality to it. I've never put so much time into an early access game. And I still have some challenges yet to beat, with TONS of new content on the horizon. If it even looks remotely interesting, you NEED to play it. Seriously, ignore the bad reviews, please. I was not payed by the devs, I just can't stand tryhards.

122786450.review:
Excellent roguelike with lots of depth and replayability. Balance your arsenal of weapons, armor, and fun consumables with Tetris-style inventory management. Your ever-expanding backpack is your method of increasing your power.

In the short time since the game's release there have already been a number of QoL improvements, challenges, and new game modes added. It's clear that the developers are looking to ensure there's enough content for even the hardcore dungeon delvers.

The game offers enough variety and characters to try that you won't feel bored or worn out by the gameplay loop. Challenging bosses require you to adjust your strategy or have your run come to an end. Each area has a very different feel, but I only wish there was more variety to the music. My main gripe is that there are items and effects that the tooltips don't completely address, so sometimes I spend my precious action points on something that doesn't go as expected. I'm the type of roguelike player who always tries to get maximum value, so sometimes it's paralysis by indecision as I try to cram every last bauble in my pack! Gladly, you can take your time if you are an organization guru.

Overall, the game is loads of fun and definitely worth a few hours of your time if you find it appealing. If you've seen the unsuccessfully kickstarted Jack and Casie, this game scratches the same itch but without the frenetic pace.

122776876.review:
The good:

- Fun, addictive game. There are some ways to create some bonkers synergies and create a godlike character. The gameplay loop is fun and different enough each time to where each run feels pretty novel while also not being too difficult to discern. While some strategies are stronger than others, every single one seems viable once you get the right cadre of items.

The Meh:

- You basically get locked into a strategy with your fist "build-around" pickup. It's not gamebreaking but due to the reliance on synergies, you don't have time to search for other potential items. And if you don't find a build-around item by the first boss? Forget it, you may as well restart.

The God-Awful:

- The name "Endless Mode" is a cruel joke. Enemy damage and HP values shoot up rapidly, faster than you can possibly deal with. The second boss in endless has almost 6,000 HP, summons enemies and enrages. I have yet to find a strategy that can get past it. Very frustrating to see enemy stats spike so aggressively for no reason.

- There are certain encounters early on that are run killers before you even have a chance to get off the ground. Specifically, there is a wizard/warrior combo that heal/armor up every round that you can run into very early on. If you are unlucky to have not found a way to deal 40+ damage a turn by the time you hit this encounter, your run is over.  Very frustrating to have found a really neat item but not have the right synergies set up yet only to die to an enemy that can just outlast you.

It might sound like a lot of compaining, but I really do love the game. I realize that it might not be for everyone, but I think the developers realized that too. It's great that the devs have offered a demo so folks can see if it is their cup of tea.

This is probably one of the best Roguelikes that I have ever played, Every time I passed up a item, I though "this is trash! why even bother with it?" only to make a build with it and wonder why its so OP. 122731819.review:
After several successful runs in the game, I didn't lose any interest in playing it. Variety of runs is huge due to the ability to beat the game with completely different setups.

Player-game interactions are generally smooth, but there are some minor UX issues. I hope developers of the game are reading steam reviews.

1. I'm tired of switching to the inventory, then to the map and back to the inventory again. It would be nice to have a little mini map on the screen and use WASD to move around the map.
2. It would be nice to have some kind of wiki inside the game to learn more about status effects and what negates what, especially for new players.
3. Some items' descriptions are still pretty hard to understand.
4. After updating inventory, item that gets bonuses for repeating adjacent items doesn't show bonuses on the first mouseover. You basically need to hover the item twice to see the recalculated bonus.

Anyway, those are minor issues. Gameplay is really entertaining, and I can say that I loved Backpack Hero. I hope it will get developed further.

8/10

122609754.review:
It seriously pains me to rate this as a no, because I love the actual gameplay of the game, but the recent/upcoming patch has introduced a change which basically changes the game completely. 

[i]With the latest patch, the full dungeon map is no longer revealed when entering a floor.[/i]

This feels like a small change to make it more 'roguelite feeling', but it drastically warps the core loop of the game of managing your backpack and minmaxing space in order to get incremental gains over time and eventually come out on top. 

Part of the appeal was the 'open information' nature of the game. A backpack is fully open information, and its up to you to decide how to organize it. The map really lent to that appeal, since you could strategically plan your exploration around your items. Things like "Should I spend a key now to regain some room in my bag when I know it could be used later for a shop?", "I should hold on to this legend in case the question mark is a 'rarity trade' event". or "I should sell stuff at this shop now, because I know theres a chest coming up and I need room for that" were strategic decisions that I as a player had to make.

Without that 'open information', I feel like Im just throwing things around in the dark, and don't have an extra layer of game on top of the combat system. Its just 'kill thing, see what I find, pigeonhole myself into a build, because I don't know if I can be flexible on this floor, die, repeat'. It feels like I have less agency and choice now, and the choices I do make are inherently devalued where they weren't before.

It might sound overdramatic to say, but this one small change has genuinely ruined the game for me. It completely removed a layer of strategic gameplay that I found engaging on top of the backpack management, and simultaneously devalues the core gameplay loop of managing a backpack's contents through tough decisions. 

I've already seen responses that say their next update is a dungeon redesign which will do things like 'add a shop to each floor for reliability', but I hope with all the similar feedback Ive seen they change it back, or even make it an option to toggle. A ""Dungeon Redesign"" can't add strategic depth like the game originally had before this was added.

As it stands now, I can't recommend it but I truly hope to be able to in the future.
122609754.developer_response:
Hey! Thank you for the kind feedback! I hope you will try the latest version on the testing branch! You can now see past enemies and you can see a lot more of the dungeon at all times. Also the dungeons are much more complex now - which hopefully explains part of the changes!

Also, if you really don't like it, some game modes have "You can see the whole floor" enabled and nothing blocks your vision at all!

We are still bug-fixing and making small changes, but this update should be posted in time for Halloween if you want to wait for the main branch to update!
